If you fancy checking it out though i would say to do so, it;s not an offensive film and obviously a lot of people really love it.

Oh and it has Alex O'Loughlin in it for about all of three minutes but he steals the damn film with those minutes and he's very, very, very pretty here. So yeah two stars for Alex. It would have been one otherwise!

August Rush started out slow, but picked up steam slowly and has become one of my all-time favorites. It was sweet, gentle, and not at all overwhelming. The movie showed courage, warmth and tenderness...loved it.

Evan Taylor (Freddie Highmore) is an eleven year old boy living in an orphanage. He has never known or met either of his parents, yet he has known most of his life that he was not supposed to be orphaned and both of his parents wanted him. He can hear things all around him, in musical tones whether it be words, wind chimes, the sound of honking horns or birds chirping, it all has a musical resonance to him. The kid is a profound musical prodigy waiting to develop. Although he has never played a musical instrument, the music is inside of him. His belief that his parents are out there somewhere and love him, as well as the music he feels his parents somehow gave to him, drives Evan to run away from the orphanage in search of them. What he finds is much more than he imagined was hiding inside of him all along.

There he meets a con artist whose street name is "Wizard" (Robin Williams), who once a prodigy like himself shares his ability to hear music in everything around him. Evan chances upon a guitar and masterfully begins to play as his natural talent becomes quite evident. "Wizard" changes Evan's name to "August Rush", partly to promote the boy's talent, and partly to disguise him as he learns Evan is a runaway and there is a search being conducted to find him. Through a course of events, the two are seperated and Evan (now "August") hides out in a church orphanage where his talent is quickly discovered and he is soon enrolled at Juliard School of Music where he composes a masterpiece the school solicits the New York Symphony Orchestra to perform.

Evan's parents were Lyla Novacek (Keli Russell) who at the time was an accomplished Cellist with the New York Symphony, and Louis Conelly (the very talented Jonathan Rhys Meyers) an Irish singer and songwriter, who met on one magical night in New York and fell deeply in love with each other. Due to horrible circumstances the two never met again. Both talented musicians left their field of music and pursued other avenues of life. One in San Francisco, the other in Chicago, far from the child neither one knows even exists. Can the faith that drives a child who thinks he can hear his parents through the music they gave him, possibly compose a reconnection of these three lives?

This movie is fantasy, and oftentimes throughout, it suffers moments of great lack of reality, nevertheless by then the viewers attention is captured in the awe of it's magic, and reality is no longer expected. The film is charming and pulls on the heart of the viewer to let go and believe in fairy tales. The music in this film is incredible. Highmore ("August") gives a stellar performance of his character and steals the show completely. Not far behind him is the performance of Jonathan Rhys Meyers ("Louis") and Keli Russell ("Lyla"). All three of these actors were perfectly suited for the part in which they were cast, performing with incredible feeling and unique talent. The well orchestrated cast of supporting actors, including Robin Williams, give very good performances of their characters as well, bringing the script together in perfect harmony.

The DVD offers a scene selection feature as well as a few additional scenes which were edited out of the production. Most of these scenes fit perfectly into the script and a couple of them would have been helpful in their original place. The only negative I can give this film is that the ending was rather disappointing. It builds up for 113 minutes and just as the viewer is expecting to see the end result of a masterful script, the movie ends abruptly. The rest is left to your own imagination. Although it was all spelled out, and the right characters were in place for the moment they belonged in, the film does not deliver the visual crescendo the viewer is longing for. The audience is left screaming for an encore that is never given. I suppose the point was for the viewer to hear the music within themselves, nevertheless it would have been much more satisfying to have actually SEEN it! I highly recommend this film for your viewing enjoyment and a very nice addition to your DVD collection.

I've seen this movie 5 or 6 times. I absolutely love it. If you have an ounce of creativity in your being, you will love this movie too. The storyline is amazing.

A young orphan boy tries to find his parents. He ends up lost/homeless on the street. He is taken in by a pied-piper of young street musicians, who lives in a run down abandoned building. His parents had a love-at-1st-sight experience, but were pulled in different directions. I won't give the storyline away, but his mom didn't know he was alive. His dad never knew he existed. The boy knew that his mom and dad loved him and were trying to find him. He felt the only way he could find them was to create music so that they could hear it...and then they would find him.

I really appreciate how this movie takes you through several different levels of art/music: amateur, sophisticated,  orchestra, rock, blues, self-taught, refined, gritty street, gospel, etc.

Parents: I don't feel that there are any more "rated R" moments in this movie than you might come across while watching a typical prime time show on TV. The artistic and emotional value of this movie is great enough to allow your tween/teen to watch.

This was one of the most unrealistic, sappy, poorly acted movies I've seen in a long time. I thought the kid who played Evan/August was terrible. In addition to what I thought were generally extremely limited acting skills, he displayed virtually no change of emotion throughout the entire movie, for which I blame the director. Being upbeat and hopeful are nice virtues to be sure, but this was ridiculous. And what kid, who is supposedly a musical prodigy no less, in his right mind would trade a free Julliard education to go back with Wizard? That was a patently stupid contrivance apparently used solely to extend the running time and ramp up the tension for the even sillier contrivance that brings them all together. Speaking of Julliard, do they routinely enroll homeless orphans who possess no identifying paperwork at all? Is that even legal?  Were they appointed his legal guardian by some competent authority or did they just assume the role on their own? Not one character in this movie came across as resembling a real human being in my opinion. Honestly, this movie was worse, in just about every way, than most movies intended for children.
This is a movie every person should see. Believe in your heart, your dreams, and don't let anyone get in your way.

I have read some 1 star reviews saying this is in no way a 5 star movie. These reviewers, if you read them are obviously music teachers or musicians that are the epitome of the bully in the orphanage. They have issues and can't accept that it's a movie and is fantasy. It is not based off real people. These people would try to force anyone with talent better than themselves to deny that talent out of jealousy. Fine, it is very exagerated that our boy can pick up sheet music and just know how to read it and compose a song in less than 1 day but like I said. It's a movie.
On to the review:
I love this movie. I am not going to start flashing names of artists they were copying for Freddie Highmore's style of playing but there are originators of it out there for longer than you think.
As we begin, we have Evan - Aka August Rush (Freddie Highmore) in an orphanage and he is bullied for being different. Flash to 11 yrs earlier to Keri Russell (Celebrated Julliard celloist) and Jonathan Rhys Meyers (budding Rock star) meeting and having a one night stand. Keri is controlled by her father William Sadler so the relationship doesn't take off.
Back to Evan in the present - He leaves to find his parents by "following" the music.
Terence Howard is the child services rep trying to find him.
Robin Williams is the person who takes him in which is the "Oliver Twist" part. He gives Evan the name August Rush as a stage name but also to hide him from the authorities in order to use his talents. Not his best work but the character was not supposed to be outright violent or dangerous. He is a guy that you just don't know how off his rocker he is or how violent he COULD be.
The rest of the movie is a show of the close calls of the father, mother and Evan coming so close to meeting it will make you almost cry. You spend the movie beginning to believe that as long as Evan is playing, his mother and father will find him.
If you have no hope, don't watch it. Or, better yet, you should be watching it.
Like a word in the tittle of the movie says rush....Wow I received this in "rush" time. 1 Day, it was great!

August Rush is an excellent storyline which is quite insightful in the search for one's identity and finding your parents.  I thoroughly enjoyed it, as a matter of fact I bought 2 copies; one for myself and another as a Chrsitmas present.

I could only say "wow" after seeing this film. August Rush is a highly beautiful film about a boy living in an orphanage. He absolutely adores everything that has to do with music and this passion of his takes him on a quest for the two aspects he misses the most in life: his parents and a fair chance to play and enjoy music. As for the acting, the sweet and sincere leading character gives an amazing performance. Still, it's the high quality melodies that make this movie really stand apart.

The following sentence heard in the film sums up it's main message: "Just listen!" This is a great piece of advice for everyone living in our stressed up world today. How often do we ignore or neglect all the gentle voices around us: the singing of birds, the sounds of wind and the expressed honest hopes and expectations of the people around us.

This story of star-crossed lovers will lift your spirits. When an Irish guitarist meets a beautiful cellist in New York, they fall deeply in love. Their child, a musical prodigy like Mozart, runs away from his orphanage (that story is a subplot since neither parent knows he's alive...) and he sets out to find his parents through his gift of music.

He takes the name of August Rush and so their song of faith and love and happy endings begins. The journey has a few jolts and there is a touch of Oliver Twist in the characters, but it is definitely a fun movie.

This is a review of the movie--not the DVD.

I first want to comment how astounding it is that the audience "Fresh" rating on Rottentomatoes.com for this movie is over 80%, whereas the critics have provided less than 35% positive reviews.  This is one where the audience needs to pull its head out of its rear and realize that a cute kid, a pretty actress, Robin Williams, and the IDEA of a good story do not a good movie make.

The concept of a wanted-but-lost child who is a musical prodigy searching for his parents, and entering into said concept as the audience with the faint promise of a happy ending, is all more than okay with me.  The problems I have is how much farther the movie demands I stretch the license I give it to ignore reality.  I'll buy that this kid can "hear" his parents, that he's the most gifted musical prodigy to have ever been born, that his grandfather is a mean and selfish man to the point of secretly giving the kid up for adoption, that somehow two people know they're "meant for each other" after a one-night-stand, and even (spoiler alert) that the boy can turn around at the end of his concert and see his parents and immediately know who they are.

I will not, however, buy that he can sight-read sheet music after a 7-year-old girl shows him what a quarter note is, or that an inner-city pastor can walk a kid through the front doors of Juilliard and get him enrolled in classes, or that such a young boy would be allowed to participate in such a high-profile concert when no one even knows who his parents are.  Also unforgiveable is the editing during the musical scenes, where the camera doesn't stop panning.  It's unforgiveable because 1) it's irritating, and 2) it's quickly obvious that the purpose is to try to distract you from the fact that the filmmakers couldn't be troubled to hire a very good musical consultant.  If you're a guitarist like me, or really any kind of musician, watching Evan and others "play" guitar is painful.  You hear solo parts when all the actors are doing is strumming, or hear the guitarist slide up on the neck and the actors move down, if at all.  Then there's the part when Evan touches a piano for the first time--it's clear as day that it's the wrong note.  And this isn't a perfect pitch kind of thing--the kid was not even at the right octave.  How is it that someone decides to make a movie that is built around music but can't be bothered to make it appear that the instruments are actually being played?

Like I said, the concept of the movie sounds beautiful, but its execution is gut-wrenching.

What an incredible story!  It left me with such a wonderful feeling that I wanted to watch it again!  I LOVED it.  I'm going to buy more then one copy so that I have a back up!  I will be watching this over and over.  It's absolutely Fantastic!!

I received the product with no delays. It was still in plastic packaging and the disc had no scratches or defects. I was highly satisfied.

Loosely based on Dickins' "Oliver Twist," Freddie Highmore plays a young boy lost in New York's childcare system, searching for his parents, who gave him up.  He runs away from the boys' home he grew up in, abused by the other kids, not the adults, who genuinely care for him.

Highmore has a gift of music, inherited from both his parents, and is quickly picked up by a Fagan like character played by Robin Williams, who sends kids out into Washington Square Park playing music for money.

Meanwhile, the boy's mother finds out that her son is still alive (she was lied to by her father, who forged her signature on the papers, giving him up.)  How the doctors and hospital went along with this is never explained, but the mother gives a decent performance, yelling at her father on his deathbed, "Where is he?"  She goes to see child care services, who after running her through red-tape, finally help her try to track down her missing son.

Williams learns the state is looking for "Evan", and changes the boy's name to "August Rush," a stage name.  The boy is quickly discovered by a priest who takes him to Juliard, and the boy is revealed to be a musical prodigy.

The tale follows Oliver Twist; Williams reclaims the boy from the school, claiming to be his father.  In the park, Freddie meets his real father, who convinces him to go to the planned concert anyway.  There, both parents are called by their son's music, and the mother recognizes him on stage from his photograph.

A very good modernization of Dickens.

I don't have a single bad thing to say about this movie. It was so awe inspiring. The only negative about the whole thing is probably Robin Williams, but only because he was such a nasty character. The music used in the movie is so beautiful and the plot/story is one of the most inspirational I've seen in a very long time. The ending has to be the ultimate in movie endings, I've seen this close to five times and I've cried every single one of those. I would even recommend NOT renting, because you can save the money you would spend that way to purchase this movie since it is more than worth it. More so on blu-ray, the details and colors are amazing.
Excellent movie, after renting it several times (older movie, scratched) I decided I wanted to own my own copy. I also bought the soundtrack from the movie, another excellent choice.

The delivery of the DVD was fast and I was happy to see the quality was very good. This was the second DVD I purchased from Amazon and I was very pleased. I recommend Amazon DVDs.

The movie is a great inspirational movie for musicians and those with the gift of music.

I highly recommend this DVD. It is a heartwarming story about an orphan boy who follows the music in his soal as he searches for his parents. He doesn't know why they gave him up but the music tells him that they love him and want him. The young actor is perfect for the role. You can't help but fall in love with him.

My husband and I watched this on HBO and fell in love with it.  I purchased this DVD so he could watch it whenever he wished, as he enjoys the story plot, the characters, and the music immensely.

If you have not seen the film, it is particulaly entertaining and is heart-warming when an orphaned child, who is a gifted musician, is reunited with his biological mother and father.  Robin Williams is also in the film.

If you like all types of music, you will enjoy this film.
A perfect movie with a perfect story of overcoming the negative and excelling at what we do best.  A wonderful story for all ages.

This is definitely one of the best ever made I definitely recommend it to anyone to see!

The parallels between this movie and Oliver, which have been pointed out by other reviewers, in no way detracts from the charm of this movie. The story of a young boy who has been left to his own resources, and discovers a haven called music is inspiring and dramatic; I can most specifically relate to using music has a source of hope and promise as a boy!

The story proceeds with a series of flashbacks that explain how the situation developed that put our talented hero in an orphanage. His love of music, which was strictly generated within him, serves as a focal point for living that helps compensate for the difficulties which life has placed before him.

August is blessed with a remarkable talent for music that places him in the child prodigy category. Having no one that cares enough to help him, he must find music in all that surrounds him; as he listens to the ordinary sounds of life he translates that into music in his mind.

A basic part of his belief system is a complete, unshakable confidence that his parents love him and want him back. This notion is ridiculed by the other boys in the orphanage but his confidence is not compromised by that.

The story takes a big turn when August, who is actually named Evan Taylor, decides to follow the music and finds himself in the totally strange surroundings of New York City. This is where a boy street musician, the "Artful Dodger" character, befriends him and takes him to meet the "Fagin" character who in this story is called The Wizard, very well played by Robin Williams.

The pace of the story picks up from this point onward; the lives of all three, the mother, Lyla, played by Keri Russell, the father, Louis, played by Jonathan Rhys Meyers, and the son, August/Evan, played by Freddie Highmore are being drawn together by their shared love of music. I will only say that the ending does not disappoint!

The copy we watched last night was loaned to us by a friend; I placed an order for a copy of our own this morning with Amazon. I'm already looking forward to seeing it again. By the way, the sound on the disc is very good; there are instrumental solos including a pipe organ that sound fabulous, as well as an unusual blending of rock and classical music used to show the dramatically different lives lead by Lyla and Louis.

We thoroughly enjoyed the movie and found it captivating!
this movie is a great inspiration to human spirit and love. I wish everyone I knew would see it, and you too (who ever you are!)

I watched this movie on cable and only saw apart of it but when it came on again it was kind of late and I had to get up early for work but it was well worth watching the parts I missed the first time. I'm not an expert critic or even a musician but this movie kept my attention and I found it to be just a good movie for all ages to watch. I know its not all real but I guess just allowing my imagination to flow with the movie and with the characters in the movie I found it to be entertaining and well worth owning and watching over and over again. Too bad for those that are so serious about their music that found this movie offensive and unbelievable.  I'm not one of them I just liked the movie and the music no mater how not real some parts may have been thats the beauty of it for me. I wasn't looking for mistakes in the movie or finding faults with the music or charters I just saw it for what it was a simple but entertaining movie to watch.

This is truly a delightful movie with spine tingling music.  My compliments to the Writers, Director, Actors and Staff Members for a wonderful performance and splendid outcome.  May everyone have a chance to experience Music & United Consciousness.

I had seen this movie on cable and wanted to make this movie apart of my best of best collection.  All audiances can appreciate it and enjoy this movie.  It is violence free and can even be shared with younger people.  I bought a copy for myself and gave my mother one for Mother's Day. She also loved it.

First I have to say I LOVE this movie.  I am somewhat cynical and rough around the edges, but this movie got to me.  "August Rush" is lovely fairy tale about a little boy, Evan Taylor, who has grown up in a state home, who is a musical prodigy.  Unbeknownst to him, he is the son of two musically gifted parents (played by the wonderful Kerri Russell and the brilliant Jonathan Rhys-Myers.  Evan is convinced he is still loved and wanted by his parents, and rightfully, as his mom was tricked into giving him up by her duplicitous father.  We meet the young lovers who connect on a rooftop, discussing music and the connection it is in their lives, only to be spearated.  Evan is sent away, his mother thinking he died in her emergency delivery.  Evan think he can reach them through music and he hears music in the most mundane of sounds.  The opening is a bluray delight(between image and audio) with Evan "conducting" the wheat colored fields of his orphanage as the wind pours through it.  He runs away one night to find his parent, convinced if he can play his music where it can be heard they will find him.  He meets a street grifter (a wonderfully dispicable Robin Williams) who tries to exploit his gifts to line his pockets and even gives him the stage name of August Rush.

The movie relies on a lot of coincidences and leaps in credibility, but the fairy tale tenor of the story makes this permissible as we feel we are watching a fable, but the genius of the movie is the realistic look and feel of the film and characters.  Freddie Highmore (Finding Neverland, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory) is brilliant.  The film is set on his shoulders and he delivers.  He is winning, lovable, and as an actor, Highnmore has a poise well beyond his years.  The film is by turns, funny, aching, lyrical, and ultimately it has its moments of sheer joy, and it earns every one of them.

The films was a must-have for me on Blu-ray between the gorgeous cinematography and fabulous meoldic score by Mark Macina.  The film is stunning in 1080p.  There is not a single flaw on the print or the high-def transfer.  Blacks are inky, colors have wonderful saturation, and there is a light veneer or grain in the image retaining the film-like look.  The Dolby TrueHD sound is a revelation, as opposed to the lossy standard track.  The scene where August plays his rhapsody the church organ is booming, exciting, with enormous detail added.  This is a fine example of how high def only enhances and serves the story rather than special effects and explosions.  The current price of this disc makes it a no brainer if you are a fan of the film.  To those new to it, this is the way to see it.  It's perfectly suitable for children (my 8 yr old LOVED it), although it is not a children's movie.  Highest recommendation.

What a nice movie, a pleasant film.  There are lots of twists and turns in this, and I kept waiting for the Hollywood version of the Greek tragedy, but it didn't happen.  This flick will leave you smiling and maybe even a bit misty eyed, a great one to watch with your spouse or SO.

Music is the backdrop, and the acting is as superb as the story is improbable.  For once Robin Williams doesn't dominate the scenes but plays the part of the benevolent scoundrel, who you'd love to hate, but can't. Freddie Highmore, the "orphan," will steal your heart and you keep rooting for him as he squirms and wriggles through one musical scene after another trying to locate the parents he is convinced are still alive - parents who all the officials assure him are no longer around.

The story will suck you in, the music, a seemingly wacky combination of classical, street and pop, will entertain you and you'll not want any interruptions while you enjoy the story. Very difficult not to rate as five-stars !!
I rented this to see if I would like it enough to buy it> I did buy it and have watched it more than once since. I also bought the sound track because I like the music.
Love this movie. Really good and touching story. Wanted to own it. Music in it is great.
I guess the fact that I really like this movie makes this a biased review. But, concerning the physical product and shipping, it was in perfect condition and quickly shipped.
Sweet fluffy re-working of OLIVER TWIST. Meyers and the kid are great. Williams & Howard decent. Russell? I'm not sure her blank disaffected stare is actually a finely honed acting skill.

I had to see this film because I am a huge fan of Keri Russell (Felicity) and Jonathan Rhys-Meyers. They don't share many scenes together but their connection and chemistry is awe-inspiring. Freddie Highmore who plays August Rush is such a special and gifted actor. This drama is hopeful, powerful, and deeply moving - I highly recommend it!

For someone who loves romantic movies, this movie certainly delivers. I loved it, I simply loved it and I can't say it any clearer than that. I wanted to feel good, I wanted to feel joyful, I wanted to feel that magical something that I can't really explain and this movie gave it to me. The plot, the actors, the music, the journey is just right for me.

Here it is nearly 1:00 a.m. and I am so alert. Really I feel energized with that kind of "you can do it" energy. I love when a movie gives me something positive. It's like a sort of nourishment.

I've just finished watching this movie and I feel like I can watch it all over again. I am uplifted, energized, hopeful, creative, and just filled with something that is inspiring and encouraging. For some, what I say will sound hokey or whatever, but hokey people like me love this kind of movie. The kind that is alright to share with the entire family. Gosh, did this movie make me feel great. I simply loved it.

I was pleased with this product. It was in the condition I was told it would be in and I received it in a timely manner.

Thank you,
The "August Rush" video is perfect for families.  It is a joy and very encouraging for children.  I really enjoyed it with my family.

Even tho there are reviewers who down the movie, it continues to be one I will watch over and over (and over).  A couple parts could be scarey for younger children (treatment by fellow orphans and Robin Willams as Wizard) and I seriously doubt if they would understand the story anyway.
I do enjoy Freddy Hightower (Finding Neverland).  Found Kerri Russel to be a breath of fresh air.  Loved the music!
True, the story line is highly improbable, but it will remain a favorite and, once again, I do have to rebuy it since I can't find my copy.  Most likely loaned it to someone for their viewing pleasure!
Not a chick flick, but a good family film. Strongly recommend.

As a musician for 30+ years, one of the most difficult things to explain to a lay-person is what SOUL is.  What HEART is.  What musicians mean when they say they were filled up inside, or taken over by music.  Watch the movie!  Fantastic performances, excellent story line, August Rush is incredible.  It immediately jumped to my Top-5 all-time, and I consider this the Wizard Of Oz of movies about music.  PG-rated only because of slight thematic elements, it's still worth watching with kids who are old enough to understand real-world (these days, that's around 7).  Watch the movie!  You've heard the phrase "feel-good" movie before, but on the mountain range of feel-good films, this is Everest.  At the summit.  Watch the movie! I'm not going to break down the story, or rate the actors individually, or give anything away.  I'll say the only 3 words that matter:

WATCH THE MOVIE!

August Rush is a breath of fresh air in a shot em up world. I laughed, I cried. I thought this movie was one of the best I have seen in awhile. It is a awesome, inspiring, really great movie, and definately worth seeing.

in hopeful anticipation of what was to come.

I absolutely loved this movie and in fact paused it so I could call my daughter 2,000 miles away to tell her she MUST see this movie!

The movie was magical. And many refer to it as a Fairy Tale and yet for me, personally, I viewed it as something very real, and THAT is what made it magical.
For I have experienced, or known of, many things that many may find unbelievable, or coincidental, or magical and yet they were the Orchestration (pun intended) beyond our own thinking.

And that magical wonder; that purposeful Orchestration is there all the time..all we have to do is listen.

I first viewed this movie about a year ago and I knew I would purchase it. The music was great. I have three children that love music and play instruments. They enjoyed the idea that music binds people together. I loved the characters. My only wish was for an ending where August and his parents actually speak, but in a way I guess that would take away from the whole theme of the movie.

This is a fantastic and inspirational movie of how a deep and determined desire can be realized with unstoppable determination to follow your dreams and make them come true.  I love this movie especially at this time in my life when it really speaks to me!!!!

I first saw this movie when it came out and just loved it. It was a winter night and as we walked out of the theater big flakes of snow were falling in the quiet night. It was such a beautiful finish to this wonderful movie. I was truly mesmerized by August Rush, and the snow added the perfect touch to the evening. I have since ordered it on DVD to add to my 'favorites' collection. This is a must see!

Passion and love for another transverses time for two people,their love child,feels that passion & love and turns it into music.

One of the greatest love stories I have ever experienced the delight in watching.
Thanks, the dvd was just as I ordered and it arrived in a timely fashion.  I've had hours of viewing pleasure. A definite must-see movie.

During a time when action and animated violent films are all the rage, it's so refreshing to see a film that makes you feel good.  It's well-written, well-acted, and has an unusual story line that keeps you on the edge of your seat.  This is a must for adult viewing.

I love love love this movie. The music is beautiful and all the acting is very good. I must say that Freddie Highmore is so adorable in this movie as Evan Taylor/August Rush. I won't give you a summary of the plot, because you can read that in other reviews, but I will say that if you are a person who wakes up in the morning and always thinks my life/this world is a black hole of depression and nothing ever good happens then you'll probably hate this movie. However, if you are a happier person and believe that this world CAN be beautiful and inspirational than you will like it. Watch it, especially if you love music.

Have seen this movie many times. It is a bit of a fairy tale imo, however, it is magical and truly inspiring as well. This movie has touched most everyone (that I've known) whom have watched it.  Anyway, have upgraded to the Blu-ray version of this film.  I've noticed a significant improvement in the picture quality. However, there seem to be audio issues with the Blu-ray version.  Specifically, the volume has to be increased (significantly/almost extremely)higher in several areas throughout playback.  Have done my checking: none of the cables are loose on either the BR player or HDtv, there are no surround sound components attached at this time, and this has not occurred with any other Blu-rays.  Perhaps this copy only has issues?? Please let me know if you experience the same problem by replying to this review...  Thanks.
One of the best movies I have seen in a while.  I saw it on HBO and had to have a copy for my Library.  Definitely one of those that you can watch over and over.

Lyla Novacek (Keri Russell) attended Julia Music Performing Arts School in New York and played the cello. Louis Connelly (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) was the member of a rock band. There was a connection between them the second they met and on that day a musical genius was conceived. The day she gave birth, Lyla's father made a choice that he claimed was for both of them, but it was really a selfish decision. Lyla no longer had her son and she was separated from Louis.
Evan Taylor (Freddie Highmore) listened to sounds of the wind, city streets, etc and he would hear music. He was in a home for boys where his gift was not appeciated because they saw him as freakishly different. He wanted to be with his birth parents, not placed in someone's home. He had no anger because they gave him up, but was consumed with thoughts of where they could possibly be and he kept believing he could follow the music that would lead him to them.
I enjoyed August Rush. Maxwell 'Wizard' Wallace (Robin Williams)bothered me a bit, though. He acted like he cared about Evan but he didn't really want this boy to be happy. He deceived him and tried to fill his mind with doubt. Wizard's thinking was all messed up because he was scarred by the foster care system. He lived in an abandoned theater with homeless children he was supposedly taking care of but he was really using them. It was a good thing Richard Jeffries (Terrance Howard) cared about what happened to Evan.
There's a scene where a choir is practicing a beautiful song and the ending touched my heart. This is a movie for the entire family.
Great movie with a great ending.  Not sure it is super special in Blu-ray vs standard DVD so if you own the DVD no need to upgrade, if not get the Blu-ray version.
this movie tells us to never give up on our dreams I know its just a story but what a lesson to learn. Great movie.

From beginning to end this movie is wonderful, charming, sad, sweet and all around a feel good film. The film follows the path of a very talented young boy who only wishes to find the parents he knows are out there and two people searching for love and returning to what made them so happy from the beginning: music. It's a true fairytale in every sense of the word and written in a way that will take your breath away. It did for me and I am left in tears everytime I watch it.

August Rush is indeed a work of art and heart.
A great fairy tale that allows the viewer to suspend cynicism for a short while and believe in the hope that there is magic in this world that is greater than what the newspaper reports.

August Rush was the cinematic equivalent of drinking straight from a bottle of Karo corn syrup.
First of all, the kid's style of guitar playing is strongly reminiscent of the late Michael Hedges so if you like that sound - and it is a very cool sound - try listening to the real thing and buy a Michael Hedges CD or go watch some of his video on YouTube.

Ok, now the ugly part... I'm a 54 year-old musician who believes music can found everywhere (one of this movie's themes).  I really related to the early part of the movie "August" is hearing melody and rhythm in various natural sounds (like the wind blowing through a field of grain)  When I was a teenager, long before the advent of sampling, I used to hear music in steam vents at an asphalt factory I worked at on the Pugent Sound.  I wanted to find a way to capture and execute that sound on strips of recording tape triggered by a keyboard (similar to a Mellotron in mechanics). I really do get the idea.  But then the movie disintegrates into a series of sappy situations and "awakening" events that are just too far fetched; this was perhaps the lamest, sappiest and most unbelievable drivel I have ever watched in my life.  Come on, did a junior high school drama enthusiast write this screenplay?

A good movie, especially fiction, has to find a way to suspend belief.  August Rush fails miserably. Sure, a savant could start playing an instrument almost immediately.  But a savant (even Mozart) couldn't sit down and start writing musical notation without even 5 minutes of study to understand the lexicon used.  That's just preposterous.  And even if the kid could do that impossible feat, how would he know the ranges and tunings of the various instruments when writing those parts.

It's too bad because with just a modicum of care and research this movie actually could have been made a little more believable.  The idea about music being every where really intrigued me and that's why I watched it.  August Rush was simply awful and an ordeal - a whirlpool of Karo corn syrup.  Yuck.  I'm all sticky now.

A friend recommended this movie.  Foolishly, I bought it.  It is such a simple-minded story.  Fake fake fake.  The dialog is fake too, and doesn't make sense at times (bad editing?).  The main adult actors are nice to look at, but the story is so lame.  Don't waste your time!
Loved the movie.  The music was so good that I also bought the soudtrack album.

After this movie, I felt alive, inspired and just wanted to bask in the joyous belief that everything works out perfectly in the end. Sure we each have our own trials and experiences in life, but if we choose, we can learn and grow from these experiences, which is ultimately why we're experiencing them in the first place, and in the end, All is well.  The Universe, God, Source speaks to all, plays beautiful music for all, it's up to us to listen, and when we do, Life gets that much sweeter.

I LOVE this movie and the ideas and hope that it portrays.
This is a wonderful film. Watch it with someone you care about and share the experience with someone else.

Suggests powerfully the notion that "there indeed is a GOD". A realm of mercy.
A family with a need for love and love of music and a willingness to surrender to the idea that "it's going to take a miracle". It holds and moves and rises to crescendo at the right moment. Highly recommend.

With all of the bad things happening in the real-world it is nice to sit down and watch a movie that has so much heart and hope. I love the music, the actors, and the emotion of this movie and decided it was one I had to add to my DVD library.  Add a bowl of popcorn and a box of tissues and you have a perfect evening.
I received great and timely service for the product and found it in the condition that it was advertised.
AUgust Rush is a very enjoyable movie. Some small lapses in reality, But if you remember it is a fairy tale, you can enjoy it more. Fine for the whole family. Enjoy.
This movie is a wonderful movie and I highly recommend it for family movie night.
Great Movie.  I loved the whole thing.  I have seen it several times because the message is great.  I would recommend this movie.

August Rush is a sweet, sentimental and somewhat formulaic film. And I love it. There's something you should know about my recommendations. I love to watch movies without knowing much of anything about them, that way the story can unfold with maximum impact. So I'm just not gonna tell you a whole lot when I recommend something so you can discover the magic, too. Rent this film and watch it. Buy this film and enjoy it again and again. August Rush August Rush [Blu-ray]

"August Rush" is -measure by measure- an artistic feat according the canons of the commercial rules of market.

A captivating and well written story about two musicians who fall in love and a child with outstanding talent will conform an amusing and heartfelt canvas that will capture your heart without concessions.

Robin Williams is superb as the merciless mercenary of the low depths, who just wants to see money and a lot of fruitful opportunities around this hyper talented teenager.

Keri Russell really ignites the screen with her pristine beauty. But the rest of the plot runs for you.
I Loved this movie, music has always touched my heart and the story line if a little far fetched is great!

On the face of it, the story is contrived and tired. The orphan seeking his family plot is older than Oliver Twist. The idea that even a savant could master both musical notation and organ performance in a day is clearly beyond absurd. But there is a sweetness to this film that transcends the obvious story flaws. And for those of us that are musicians, it captures the some of the magical effect that music can hold for the performer/listener. The performances, both acting and musical, are excellent...especially Jonathan Rhys Meyers, who is as gifted in real life as the main character. Turn off your left brain and let the music entrance you.

I'm actually quite surprised at how much positive reviews this movie has received!  Granted, over dramatized unrealistic fantasy is a game Hollywood has been playing ever since the motion picture industry was invented, I really felt the makers of this movie ran with it and managed to take it to the next level.  Aside from totally unbelievable yet predictable plot line, this movie seems to forget the reality that any serious musicians come to terms with - music is 10% inspiration and 90% perspiration.  What's more, this movie seems to reinvent the term 'musical prodigy' as some kind of a monster who could play anything he hears in his head w/out any type of training.  I watched this film b/c few people mentioned it to me b/c I'm a guitar player.  I really regret renting it and having to sit through it.  I guess if I weren't a musician, I might have enjoyed it a little more.  But, I was really turned off by this movie b/c it was a total misrepresentation of how real music works.  My high school teacher, who used to be a lawyer, always complained how he couldn't stand the Hollywood courtroom drama scene...I completely understand him...

I had been told that "August Rush" was an exceptional movie, but had no idea how wonderful it is.  I've had the DVD for two weeks and have watched it seven times.  I've watched it with my family, loaned it to a friend and watched it alone.

This beautiful movie is all about love, faith, interconnection of souls and has a conclusion that makes watchers want to stand up and cheer while wiping their eyes and smiling.

I'd like to give a copy of this DVD to everyone.  It's a treat for the soul.  The music is exceptionally beautiful and weaves the story together perfectly right through to the end.

Great movie to keep passing on between friends. My dad has seen it multiple times and insists on still watching it again. It is a serious movie that I wouldn't call sad. Has a few sad moments but they become happy. Definately recommend this movie for old or young viewers.

This movie shows you how much music can really move a person. August Rush follows a family that is brought together through music. August wishes to find his long lost parents and believes he can find them through the music that he hears in everyday objects and sounds. Years before his parents had also been brought together when both "heard the music" as they were playing in two seperate concerts. As this movie progresses music continues to play as an important role as August learns how to play a guitar simply by looking at another kid playing, finds out how to write music, and finally writes his own rhapsody. As August is improving his ability and sharing his talent, his parents are each on a journey to discover they're love of music again. The end of this movie is an emotional thrill and the final song will break your heart everytime. I thoroughly enjoyed this musical movie that shows that music can bring those we miss together.

I feel this movie really tears at one's emotions in a good, happy way. It's about an orphan boy who believes that one day he'll find his parents through the use of his music. It has a really great story, even though a lot of it is hard to believe. Like the fact that the boy never had any musical training, but can pick up a guitar for the first time and automatically just start playing it like a pro, or how he had never seen a note written down before in his life yet somehow is able to write an entire musical score in a half a days time.

I do want to say that the music in it is amazing. Very catchy, yet emotionally powerful.

All the same, this is a great family movie which is enjoyable and fun to watch as long as you don't pay too much attention to how impossible some of what happens really is. But hey, what else is fiction for other then to suspend reality a little bit?

I fell in love with this movie when I first saw it, and decided that I just had to have it in my collection of movies.  Freddie Highmore is adorable as August Rush, and does a good job showing his struggle to find his parents. This is a great family film, with a wonderful cast.

It disappoints me when I see reviews for movies like this that are full of complaints about sensationalism, and incredulity.
There are some movies where a heavy hand of reality is vital to it's success. But does that mean ALL movies need complete fidelity to reality? What a sad world it would be without the fantastic realms of existence awakened in the imagination. Think of all the movies that would never have been!
Of course it would it not only be improbable, but preposterous for the story told in August Rush to happen in reality. Who cares? Is that the point of the movie? Not at all! The point is to rouse our child-like imagination and to unleash potential and motivate us to dream.
I love this movie. I get lost in the story every time--always anxious down to the last moment if they will find each other in the end.

I normally only watch sci-fi and fantasy, but this was a good movie- it sort of is a fantasy (a fable as others have said), where music is the magic.  It's about hopes, dreams, courage, and perseverance.

I don't like that the premise for the story revolves around a one-night stand, but if you can ignore that and focus on the good- they boy having to live his life trying to believe he wasn't just abandoned (when so many others were and resent his positive attitude)- you'll enjoy it.

Also, Robin Williams plays a good bad-guy. :-)

I really love this movie - every time it was on cable I HAD to watch it so I decided I NEED to own it.  It is a great mood lifter.  I smile and cry every time.  I enjoy the music and the way it informs the story.  It stimulates my own creativity.

YES THIS HAS ENGLISH CLOSED CAPTIONS FOR THE HEARING IMPAIRED and is a GREAT movie.  GREAT story. i grew up with a young man from an orphanage he was always smiling and laughing but you could see the far away look in his eyes.  i really could see him in this story.

"The music is all around, all you have to do...is listen", August Rush

Evan is an 11 year boy, who lived all his life in an adoption agency, waiting all his life to find his parents, whom he is sure love him and can't wait to see him.
He listens to all the musical sounds in nature, which he believes will help him find his parents. His parents did not know he even existed, but they always sensed a feeling in the air that he does. He follows the music until he reaches New York. He learns how to play music there until he develops into becoming a genius musician. He joins one of the best music school there. After a short while he becomes a professional music compser. One night he composes music infront of thousands of people, turns his back and finds his parents looking at him with pride and love, and they finally get back together with him after long 11 years.

This movie is magnificent. The story is very original, the casting is great, and its very emotional and touchy as well.

A movie about the very precious relationship betwen parents and their children, particularly between a mother and her child.
We take our parents for granted, however there are many people who would wish to spend 1 day with their parents, when they can't.

Love your parents. Give them the care and love they deserve. You will not know how much they love you until you yourself become a parent.

Wonderful film!

Unbelievable and yet believable. Impossible that this movie could come together this way and yet you want to believe it so bad. Quite a part for Robin Williams. He can play a creep so well as he has in other movies. Do savants learn that fast?? Perfect characters for the movie and Kerri Russell is so incredibly beautiful. Nuff said.

The only person who could enjoy this film would be someone who could completely suspend all belief in reality. The story is so far fetched that it is laughable. It draws from various sources not least of which is Oliver Twist, with Robin Williams in the role of Fagin. I have read some of the reviews which praise the film and I am frankly amazed. I have seen worse films but am struggling to name them !!!!
This film is my absolute favorite film.  A great fairytale for music lovers.  Heart warming and moving, this movie will inspire some to do great things.

I was so moved by the music in this movie.  And the story is so heart warming.  I bought a new one and a used one so I could share it with friends and family.  I also bought the soundtrack.  I just love this movie.

I have all of Alex O'Loughlin's work on DVD, so of course I had to add August Rush. I had seen it in the theater after discovering Alex on Moonlight. Alex would have been cast as the lead of this film, but was told that a "bigger name" was needed. Alex was still fairly new to the industry in the US after being a leading man in Australia. I admire his bravery, coming to the US and basically starting over from scratch. He is a brilliant talent, and should have had the lead in this movie. Since JRM was chosen due to his "bigger name", the part of Marshall Connelly was made larger for Alex since he made such an impression. In my opinion, as always, Alex outshines everyone else in this film. I saw it at the theater and then bought the DVD - just for Alex. Alex is Australian and can do any accent - his Irish accent as Marshall is impeccable. I actually have a friend who is Irish, and she said that it was funny that Alex's accent was better than JRM's, since JRM is Irish.  Alex also plays his own guitar and sings in the scenes where they show the brothers' band days, and his talent shines through there as well.
I have known people who didn't know who Alex was when they saw August Rush (Moonlight had just premiered. Then when they did see him in Moonlight and in some of his other movies later, they said, "oh, that's the guy I liked so much in August Rush!" No matter how small the part, Alex always makes an unforgettable impression.
Bottom line - buy this movie and enjoy Alex O'Loughlin. You will be glad you did.

I was surprised how much I loved this feel good, happy ending fairy tale with comforting music. It was my 'toe in the water' step outside of classical music and it was surprisingly enjoyable. The story was sweet and the acting was pleasant. I watch it whenever I want to relax.

This movie has been clearly depicted on here by quite a few people so I will not take the time to go through every aspect of the plot.  In general the movie is creative, the music really adds to the plot line, and the music itself is quite solid.  In fact I also went back and purchased the soundtrack, something I do not do often.

For music lovers this movie is perfect.  It really can touch us on a deeply emotional level and gives us a new aspect at which to look or better yet where to listen for music.  Sometimes it can happen in the most unusual circumstances.

Overall this movie was fantastic.  The acting was great, the plot was fantastic, and the music did not let you down one bit.  If you are a bit of a rut this movie can definitely lift your spirits.
Definitely the best movie of all time for me. I've never watched a movie three times in a row immediately after I saw it the first time. SOOOOooo good.

August Rush is a delightful movie.  With fantastical qualities, this heartwarming story gets the viewer emotionally involved through its amazing and dynamic music.  With an open mind, this story will touch you in a way most movies cannot.

I liked it.  I realize that it wasn't real believable, but it is marketed as a fairytale, so I didn't expect it to be a factual drama.  It's a very pleasant, romantic movie.  Not an Oscar noteworthy movie... just entertainment that makes you feel good after watching.

I have purchased this DVD because I found it beautiful as a story and of course the music.
Looking for your real parents from a child's point of view is a lifetime achievement. This story could very well be a real story that some children experienced in their own lives. The genius part of it though,is a little bit more difficult.we are not in the Renaissance period where artist,composers,painters,scientist,astrologers,are born. In my opinion there are very few geniuses in our mist today.
Sad,however looking at this movie you get inspired to listen to sounds around you,to be hopeful for the future,and to keep dreaming that dreams can and do come true. Be it in finding what you want and accomplishing your goal.

Finally I got to see this movie and loved it.  The story of an orphaned boy who's parents connected love at first sight, had a one night stand, and conceived a child.  The mother played the cello, and father played in an alternative rock band.  The baby was taken from the mother and told he was dead by her very own father and given away for adoption.  After 11 years, on his death bed, father tells his daughter about the baby, and she begins a frantic search for him in New York City.  Evan taylor, who took the alias as August Rush, was extaodinarily talented and could 'feel the presence of his parents through sounds, and he was able to compose and play music as if he'd studied all of his life.  The couple reunites in New York City to find their 11 year old son conducting a rhapsody he'd written and was performing in cetral Park.  What a lovely story to say the music connects us and brings us together, and as artists, we have a sense of perception and being that trascends all time and distance.  A must see.

Alright, let's get this out of the way.  Is this story plausible or even probable?  Nope.  Having stated the obvious, let's move on.  This film is part fairytale & part fantasy but it's told under the cloak of realism.  Yes there are child prodigies and those who just have all kinds of musical kowledge stuffed into their heads.  I tend to see that kind of thing as a gift from God.  Do people hear music in every day living through ordinary sounds?  Of course.  I suggest that one not overthink this film.  It's not that kind of movie.  It's quite a fanciful tale but it really is very enjoyable.  Jonathan Rhys Myers is always wonderful and he does not disappoint here.  Robin williams is also very effective.  The music in this movie is eclectic.  If you don't like one tune you're bound to like one of the others.  This film took me by surprise.  There's no use in describing it to you.  Just read the synopsis and then view the film.  I found it quite interesting and men will probably see it as a "chick flick."  Okay,so, no harm done.  If you're looking for car chases, guns and drugs, this isn't the movie for you.  This is more of a feel good type show.  Just take it for what it's worth and enjoy.  This film is rated pg.

I just saw this movie the other night, and the story moved me so much!

Lyla and Louis meet at a party. They share a night on top of the roof of the building, and later plan to meet again. Louis even takes a picture of Lyla. Sadly, Lyla's father has other ideas, and right in front of Louis, she's whisked away, while he frantically calls her name. What neither of them know is that that night resulted in a baby. Who by cruel ways, is separated from his parents.

Flash forward 11 years. Evan Taylor lives at a home for boys, and is constantly tormented because he hears music in everything, and has a firm, unshakable belief that his parents really wanted him. A social workek takes pity on him, and gives him his number should he ever need anything. One night, Evan slips away, setting off to find his parents.

Did i mention that Louis is looking for Lyla? He's kept that polariod of her all this time, and wants to find her. So he tries.

The whole movie is so touching and heart wrenching at times, you're just begging, "please let this boy find his parents."

The ending, just wow. Watch this, you will not be disappointed
This movie just hit me straight at my heart... tender beautiful movie with a great soundtrack too.  Will watch this movie a million times and never get tired.
This is one of the best movies and stories I have ever seen. I loved all the characters. I wished they had a better ending cause it left me wanting more.

This movie is brilliant.  It is one of the most touching movies about family and faith that I have ever seen.  The music is incredible, and the visual images are breathtaking.  The story is one of an orphan and his parents, who reunite through their music and their faith.

If you are the type of person that needs absolutely every detail of a movie to be perfect and to jive without any flaws or "how could that possibly happen" moments, this isn't for you.  But if you are looking to be inspired and for an uplifting, hopeful story, this is perfect.

For young children, I would not recommend this movie, because there are some elements that would probably frighten them.

A beautiful movie!
