From the trailers I knew I was going to like this movie, and as soon as it hit the street, I went to see it.... and I loved it!!  I started crying the minute the movie started, and it was not just sadness, it was a strong emotion I just couldn't resist.  What an amazing movie, Freddie Highmore's performance wonderful, as always.  He really got to me!

Some people hear the rhythm in a step, the strident beauty of a police siren, the whip of a powerline in the wind.  Evan Taylor (Freddie Highmore) doesn't get a decent night's sleep in the orphanage because of it.  His fellow inmates call him freak because he believes both his parents are living and they'll come for him--if only he call out with the music that connects them.

As he says, "I believe in music the way some people believe in fairy tales." So, Evan decides after eleven years and some days to escape the orphanage and go find the music--and his parents.

Even ends up in New York City with zero street smarts.  He really doesn't even know how to cross the road. A fortunate encounter puts him near Arthur (Leon G. Thomas III), a street busker his age who's willing to help--for a price. Arthur introduces him to Wizard (Robin Williams) who gives musically talented street kids a place to stay in exchange for half their take. The Wizard quickly discovers that Evan, who he renames August Rush, is a prodigy and is making some plans for the lad.

Meanwhile, we learn that Even's mom Lyla Novacek (Kerri Russell) had only been with Louis Connelly (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) one night. The Julliard educated cellist was in an accident while pregnant and her father decided to sign her name and give up her son--telling Lyla that he'd died.  Instead of the stage career her father envisioned, Lyla mostly gave up music and taught--til Julliard called her for a special concert in Central Park.

Louis has always longed for Lyla, the girl who got away.  He gave up his music and became a manager.  When he brings a girl to meet his family, they play a song he'd written for the band after Lyla's departure from his life.  He's determined to find Lyla.  When he believes she is married, he ends up in New York with no particular goals in mind except to find his music again.

"August Rush" is just as much about the musical ties that bind us as the three people whose stories it tells.  In my opinion, the best performances were the kids: Evan-August, Arthur and Hope (Jamia Simone Nash). This trio kept you captivated and cheering.

Of course, the soundtrack is fabulous.  You have Kaki King on the guitar as well as vocals from John Legend and John Ondrasik (Five for Fighting fame). I'm ordering the soundtrack tonight and I really don't often like movie soundtracks well enough to order.

I wasn't the only person who'd give this film 5 stars.  This is one of the rare films I've attended where many of the audience stood and applauded at the end.  While this is a family film, I did notice that some of the younger children got restless and needed some explanation of what was going on.

I went to see this movie without having seen any reviews (a friend convinced me to go), and so I didn't know what to expect. It didn't take me very long to be engrossed in the film, but the highlight was definitely when the lead character, 11-year-old Evan Taylor, starts playing the music he hears. It's so inspirational, and the music is so different and amazing. I loved it. A beautifully made film with such a lovely message. I appreciate a previous review that explained that the movie is a fairy tale. And it is, full of the sweetness, vitality and greatness that we all hope for in real life.

The other two reviews tell the story. I saw it with my wife and son and his wife - we all loved it. Treat your self to hearing the music that really is all around us. See this movie. Tell your friends to see this movie. Help make the world a better place

"August Rush" is a fairy tale. It doesn't have princes, princesses, evil stepmothers, witches, or big bad wolves, but it's a fairy tale nonetheless. And as such, it tells a story that resonates so strongly with its audience that it casts a magic spell. This movie is told in the language of music, and it exemplifies the harmonic connections between people, the rhythmic bonds that can never be broken in spite of distance and time. It's also told in the language of faith, of the belief that love will indeed conquer all. No, this is not a realistic idea, but that's not the point. Isn't it nice that we have films like this to escape to when realism is bringing us down? Isn't it wonderful when we find that one film that can raise our spirits? "August Rush" was that film for me, and I recommend it to anyone in need of a rejuvenating emotional boost.

The film stars Freddie Highmore as an orphan named Evan Taylor, a quiet yet determined musical prodigy. He was born as the result of a chance encounter between two musicians: an Irish rock guitarist named Louis Connelly (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) and a classically trained American cellist named Lyla Novacek (Keri Russell). While living in New York City, they met and separated through twists of fate--Lyla's controlling father (William Sadler) doesn't take the news of her unplanned pregnancy very well, and when she's hit by a car and injured, he uses that opportunity to make her believe that her baby did not survive. In reality, the baby was delivered and put into the legal system as a parentless orphan. Lyla and Louis go their separate ways, believing that they would never see each other again.

In the present day, their eleven-year-old son Evan lives in an orphanage with a number of broken-spirited boys. They're so disillusioned that they bully him into believing as they do. They constantly tell him that no one is coming for him, that his ability to hear music in everything makes him nothing more than a freak. And they will not stand for his belief that he actually hears the music of his parents calling out to him. But Evan refuses to sink to their level of hopelessness; he runs away to New York City, where the music seems to be beckoning him towards his destiny. It's there he meets Wizard (Robin Williams), a shady musician who houses a number of musically inclined children in an abandoned theater. He, too, is beaten down by life, so much so that he uses these children for his own financial gain. When he discovers Evan's natural ability to play the guitar, he gives him the pseudonym August Rush and forces him to perform in parks and on street corners.

Lyla, meanwhile, is living in Chicago as a music teacher. Single and without any children, she seems complacent yet stable in her new life. But all that changes when (1) she's offered a change to once again play with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, and (2) she learns that her baby did not die eleven years ago. With a powerful yet unexplainable determination, she travels back to New York on a quest to find her long lost son, a quest that will hopefully be added by her playing of the cello. Hoping to help find Evan is Richard Jeffries (Terrence Howard), a social worker who met the boy when he was still living at the orphanage.

And then, of course, there's Louis, who has since gone on to be a businessman in San Francisco. His band members haven't forgiven him for leaving, least of all his brother, Marshall (Alex O'Loughlin). But worst of all, Louis hasn't been able to forgive himself, and upon seeing footage of himself performing on stage, he remembers the love he felt for Lyla. The memory is so strong that's he vows to reunite with her. This journey of finding lost love leads him from Chicago back to New York City, where he's inspired to rejoin with his band and restart his singing career. Much like his son--whom he doesn't know exists--Louis is a gifted guitar player; one can hear his passion and energy with every chord, and his music operates at the same frequency as Lyla's cello playing.

As you can probably tell, most of the film thrives on serendipity, and it gets more and more prominent with every passing scene. A kind-hearted pastor eventually takes Evan in, and when made aware of his musical genius, they send him to the Julliard School of Music. He composes a piece within the first six months of his stay, one that the faculty believes is good enough to be performed. Thus sets into motion the events leading to one of the most satisfying endings of any movie I've seen this year, a scene so touching that I was in awe. As I listened to Evan's "August's Rhapsody," I felt as if I had been enveloped in the folds of hope, love, and happiness; the earthiness of the chimes blended perfectly with the smoothness of the violins and the energy of the guitars, all of which made his unwavering faith in the power of connection perfectly clear.

This is the magic of "August Rush," a film so wonderful that I cannot recommend it enough. It's a modern day fable with a timeless message, and it comes across so well that I never once stopped to consider how implausible it is. Plausibility doesn't even come into play, here. What does come into play is the emotional impact, the sense that we can get something out of it if we surrender to pure fantasy. Evan opens the film by saying, "Music is all around us--all we have to do is listen." This is one of the year's best films, and if you keep that quote in mind when seeing it, you'll be more inclined to agree.
No matter what your preference in movies, this is simply one of the most heartwarming movies ever made.  If you are not touched by this movie, check your pulse.

This is one of my favorite "feel good" movies.  It's a love story told from the perspective of the three lead characters, who share their love of music: the orphan who believes his parents are alive and that his music will bring them together, the mother who thinks her son died at birth, and the father who got separated from his true love when her parents moved the family away, and he has almost given up hope that he'll ever find her.  It has that magic feeling that reminds me of being a kid and going to Disneyland.  Very heartfelt story with a bit of a fantasy flavor. It's a bit like "Oliver" with Robin Williams playing the Fagan role.  Although it's predictable, I enjoy the way the story unfolds.

August Rush is a story both of excellent music and of the journeys of the human heart.  I won't spoil the movie for others by getting too deeply into the plot, but is well crafted and intricate.  Some of the guitar work is among the most innovative and startling of any that I've heard in 60 years of interest in the instrument.  August's organ solo and major symphonic debut piece might send chills down your spine.

Freddy Highmore is brilliant in the title role (a pseudonym from his street life in New York City).  He is well supported by Keri Russell as Lyla Novachek -- his mother --  Jonathon Rhys Meyers as Louis Connolly -- Lyla's lover for just one night and the father of August-- and Robin Williams as Maxwell "Wizard" Wallace, a small-time promoter and con artist who tries to exploit August in a ring of NYC panhandling kids to rival anything from David Copperfield. There is no way this intricate fantasy of a lost child prodigy can be regarded as low-key.  But it will engage and entrance you.

This is by far my favorite movie of all time.  Perhaps because I'm a musician and so it is very meaningful to me.  It is a moving story about a boy who is born with an incredible gift, but is orphaned at birth.  He is convinced that if his parents hear his music they will come for him.  There is so much more to the movie than that but I don't want to ruin any of it for you!  I highly recommend this film.  Kerri Russell and Jonathan Rhys are amazing as August's incredibly talented musician parents.  Robin Williams also plays an amazing role as Maxwell "Wizard" Wallace, a vagrant musician who teaches homeless children music, and uses them as street musicians to make money for him.  Freddie Highmore plays Evan Taylor aka August Rush the orphaned boy searching for his parents. There are so many other amazing actors and actresses that I don't have space to name them all. I found the music in this movie to be fantastic as well and had to download the whole sound track!

It's not a new movie, but it's extraordinary. Both a friend of mine and I (who watched the movie separately) were so moved at the end that we couldn't speak. Some of the reviewers at the time it was first released failed to grasp the point, I think. This is not fundamentally a sappy story about a family coming back together. Rather, it's a breathtaking celebration of the mystical nature of music and sound. It's effect was so powerful that everything I heard when I returned home after seeing the movie was magnified, and everything I did seemed to suddenly have a new rhythm to it. One of my favorite movies ever!

As a little girl, I loved going into the darkened theater to be transported by the images on the screen.  In those years, I'd surely have been enthralled by this magical story.  It would have appealed to my little girl imagination.

As an adult, however, I felt too often bored by this movie.  I understand that it's meant to be a metaphor for the ties that bind, as well as for the energies and connections in our lives that are invisible, and yet, they influence us.  Even as a metaphor, however, the movie seemed far too predictable--but again, only for an adult, because for a child, it'd be just fine.  Due to the predictable story line, the pace was often slow.  As an adult, I wanted to learn more about the parents than I did, although their acting was fine.  So was the boy's.  (As for the one villain, it really was hard to let go of how I regard Robin Williams in order to believe him in this nasty role.  I'd have preferred the casting of someone easier to picture as a flat out user.)

For a child who would genuinely wonder as the movie went along, how it'd all turn out, the pace would be just fine.  A child would likewise not notice that the boy was not actually playing the music he allegedly performed (but for this adult, me-thinks that aspect of the movie could have been far better crafted).

Even if I regard this movie as a metaphor, I am not persuaded.  I was put off by the fact that this was a fairy tale, but its setting was current reality.  That fostered too much incoherence for me, because there was no explanation for the basis of the "magic.'  Consequently, the movie never successfully got me to suspend my sense of reality.  (To illustrate what I mean by that, even as an adult, I enjoyed the Superman movie series, which also featured "magic" within a realistic setting.  It worked for me, however, because the basis for Superman's magic had been well-established--so I was easily able to enter into reality suspension from the outset.)

Again, if I were a child watching this, such incoherence wouldn't even show up on my radar.  I'd simply go with the magic implied--unconsciously identifying with it as the kind of magic which naturally exists inside any child's imagination.  All children "know" that their parents will find them again if they are lost.  All children can believe in fantasies where playing one's own music can make an upside world become right again.

If I had children 11 or under to whom I wanted to show a movie, I'd be glad to show them this one.  I think it's a fine little family-type story---nothing stupendous, but still some wholesome entertainment.  Like a few of us dissenters here, I am thoroughly surprised that so very many adults went wild over this movie.  Had I not paid a few dollars to rent it, I really doubt I'd have stuck with it all the way through.  As it was, I paused the movie at least twice to return my reading.  I did eventually see it through to the end, but the effort was laborious.
I love this movie.  Buy multiple copies to be used as gifts every so often.

Good little family movie. Life is full of strange unexplainable/coincidental moments so it didn't really seem too out there for me and is no more or less plausible than any other movie I've seen, spiritual faith and life in general. It centered around a specific location and beyond the family's psychic connection with each other and the boys ability to know where to find them, I didn't really have to stretch my imagination. No one flew, turned blue and time didn't shift. The writers/director fit as much as they could into this movie without making it hours long and the soundtrack was great. As for the little boy, musically gifted people and those that are not can have genius children. Some people can see music like that. I know a man that sees notes as specific colors, not to mention people with forms of autism who have photographic memory and artistic talent. More than half the people who've watched this like it, so I'm thinking it's just personal taste. If you've watched this and hated it that's fine. That's life. You've tried something new and it's time to get over it. Buying or renting this movie costs less than taking a gamble at a theater, so it's really not that devastating and is more a case of self important whining. I've thrown away a few movies in my time that people thought the world of but I've never tried to stop people from making up their own minds.

When mention the word----music, I think it is my whole world. I began to learn the violin when I was four years old. So, everything about music all appeals to me. And August Rush is just a movie, which has music as its theme throughout the whole story.

In my perspective, the movie is highly worth to see because it full of positive energy. It can bring hope to those children who live in the orphanage and dream to find their parents. Always having faith and confidence is one of the most significant things the movie taught us. Whats more, for some people who are interested in music, especially classic music, like me, this movie can make us have a further understanding about the magic power of music. Music exists everywhere. It has life, and can lead us to close our dream.

About twelve years ago, Lyla, a young beautiful cellist encountered a handsome man by following the music. The man named Louis is also a musician. They fell in love with each other in the first sight and had a wonderful night. However, their background is so different that Lyla's father forced them to break up. Lyla was pregnant after that night. But before the baby was born, she had an accident. In order not to affect her career, Lyras father sent the baby to an orphanage and told her he already died. From then on, Lyla and Louis never saw each other again, and both of them give up their music career. Many years later, the baby grew up. He is a cute boy, and very sensible to music. Every sound in this world can become a graceful melody in his ears. He is optimistic and has a faith that his parents must be waiting for him. Therefore, he left the orphanage, and began his long journey to looking for his parents.

In the whole movie, the plot that touched me most is when August playing the guitar with Louis in the corner of a street. The boy totally doesnt know the man in front of him is just his father. However, because of music., they meet each other, because of family tie that exist come with birth, they feel uncomfortable when its time to say goodbye. In my opinion, this part is very successful, since it compounds two most important themes of this movie. We can easily feel how much power the love of music and blood relationship has.

According to all above, I think this movie suits everyone regardless of children or adult. Therefor, watching it, and you will gain a lot!

This is my favorite movie of all time. I am a white male, 76 years young and have been a movie addict all of my life. Have watched a lot of great movies with very talented casts, but none have ever touched me as this has. This movie is a modern, semi- believable' fairy tale love story. I have watched it more than five times and each time I watch it I fall deeper in love with the characters and the story. My top five movies in order are, August Rush, Dances with wolves, Legends of the fall, The notebook and Second hand Lions. They all involve the power of love. John Wayne is my favorite actor and Elizabeth Taylor my favorite actress. August Rush will never be removed from my top spot. I sincerely bow to the people involved in the writing and production of this movie.

Freddie Highmore and Robin Williams combine for an interesting story where a young homeless boy holds onto hope that his parents will find him...all they have to do is hear his music.  Unbeknownst to him, his parents are both musicians - one a concert cellist and the other a singer in a ska band.  So the music courses through the young boy's veins.

Robin Williams skillfully plays a Fagin-like role as he leads/cares for/intimidates/profits from a group of homeless children in the city.

The music is mesmerizing, the story line is just believable enough to work, and the entire film is largely satisfying.

All in all a solid 4-star offering

This movie is really awesome. I think it sends a good moral message about the beauty of life and the gift that children are. I really liked this film even though some parts of it I don't agree with (premarital sex for example), but what is interesting is that even though Lyla got pregnant, she decided to keep her child. Many people today would have told her to have an abortion or something but she kept it even though she did not have a father to raise her child with. This movie wonderfully shows the value and worth of the human person and that every child should have a chance to live. Later when Evan is grown up we as the audience are presented with a loveable character who is so gifted and talented with music, that we cant help but fall in love with his character. It is kind of sad however that such a talented and lovable kid is being raised in an orphanage when he deserves two parents who are committed in marriage. But this is seriously one of my favorite movies, its a feel good movie but at the same time it presents an accurate and realistic depiction of what happens in our society today, people don't want to have kids, people don't respect other human beings, etc, etc. This movie puts a personal character in our faces and helps us to see humanity and life for what it really is and how valuable and awesome it is to be human, and what a gift our lives are.

The unreality of music leading a kid to find parents he doesn't even know are alive initially made this movie too much of a stretch to take seriously.  Then we have all the musical improbabilities.  The first time the kid picks up a guitar, he starts playing a tapping, open tuned style.  But earlier we saw that same guitar tuned normally, so this would not have worked.  When Keri Russell "plays the cello", despite the quick edits, we can see she has no vibrato, and does not use the bow properly (except when they show someone else's hands doing it).  Jonathan Rhys Myers sings well, but his guitar chords look as if they were faked (I'm not sure about this one).  Then the kid is "taught" musical notation in twenty seconds by another kid, who says things like, see, it's f-a-c-e for the spaces, and e-g-b-d-f for the the lines.  How anyone who doesn't know music would have any understanding of that is bad enough, but the kid then starts writing notes on the paper, composing.  I thought he'd play the piano, but he has learned musical notation in 30 seconds.  He then starts playing the organ without ever being shown which notes on it correspond to the notes on paper.

Many people loved the music, but except for the Jonathan Rhys Myers songs, and the Kaki King guitar style, it was very unoriginal.  August's Rhapsody started with some Bach, and then included several other themes from classical and rock music.  To me it was very uninspiring, certainly nothing a young, cool musician would ever come up with.

But...despite all of this, the movie moved me at the end, and had me rooting for them all to get together, as I was overwhelmed (maybe manipulated) by the images and beauty of the ending.

On the surface, August Rush is a movie about a kid with amazing musical talents, in search of his parents who, due to tragic circumstances, don't know he exists. As a simple romance movie, it may seem to fall a little flat.

But August Rush is not meant to be a simple romance movie. For me, August Rush is a deeply spiritual movie about soul mates and the inter-connectedness between all things - living and non-living. The very first opening lines, spoken by the enchanting young star, Freddie Highmore, say, "Listen. Can you hear it? The music. I can hear it everywhere. In the wind, in the air, in the light. It's all around us. All you have to do is open yourself up. All you have to do is listen." This movie asks that of you. To really understand August Rush requires that you listen with your heart.

There are those that believe, spiritually, that God is actually everything. God is you, and me, and the flowers, trees, air, sky, etc. Scientists and mathematicians say that everything in our world - even the patterns in the air currents - can be expressed as a mathematical equation. There is even a theory now of the "God Equation". And of course, the connection between music and mathematics has long been studied by human beings. I believe that the creators of August Rush had all that in mind when they made this lovely movie.

Evan (Freddie Highmore) is an eleven year old boy, living at the Walden County Home For Boys - an orphanage. He doesn't fit in. His understanding of music and his unshakable belief that he can hear his parents out in the world set him apart from the other boys. They are jealous and intimidated by his faith and they lash out, calling him Freak. But Evan is undaunted, believing he gets the gift of hearing from his parents and that if he can learn to make the right music, they will hear him too.

His parents are Lyla Novacek (Keri Russell), and Louis Connelly (Jonathan Rhys Meyers). When they met, Lyla was an extraordinary cellist and Louis was the singer and lead guitarist in a rock band. They both heard the same music their son hears and they were drawn to each other in a soul mate kind of connection that led to one magical night of romance and passion (and the conception of their son).

When they awoke the next morning, they knew they were meant to be together forever. But when Lyla goes back to get her things, her father (William Sadler) comes down on her with an iron fist, stopping her from following her heart, and breaking Louis' when he sees them driving away. He leaves the band shortly after that - the music just hurts too much.

When Lyla turns out to be pregnant, her dad continues to convince her to stay for her own good. When Lyla wakes up from a frightening medical emergency that resulted in the birth of her child, her father tells her that the baby "is gone", leading her to believe it died. Lyla's heart is broken by the entire experience and she walks away from music, as well, becoming a teacher in Chicago.

Lyla and Louis never forget each other. They never stop sensing that something is missing from their lives. They don't know what it is, but they sense it, catching fleeting glimpses with their hearts.

Their son, however, believes completely. He runs away from the orphanage, determined to learn how to express his own music while listening for his parents to guide his journey. As all three of them open their hearts, they are drawn ever closer on an amazing journey of faith, beauty, and music that shows the patterns of inter-connectedness between the three of them (and around us all.)

I absolutely adore this movie. As a musical person and a spiritual person, August Rush speaks to me on multiple levels. I find it a joy to watch, no matter how many times I see it.

Watching the interweaving of circumstances and characters, the near misses they experience and the ways that they interact without even realizing they are doing it, moves me. I watch and I think about the patterns in my own life and the way things have worked out in seemingly mysterious ways at times. This movie makes me feel more connected to the magic all around me.

The cast is truly enjoyable. I am so impressed with Freddie Highmore. He comes across as an old soul in a young body, wise beyond his years and unafraid to believe. Terrance Howard is Richard Jeffries, the caseworker that teaches Evan to whistle and seems to be the first person who sees how special he is.

The late, great Robin Williams is Wizard - a "broken elf" kind of person who is an intriguing combination of light and dark. He clearly knows music, describing it to Evan as, "God's little reminder that there's something else besides us in this universe, a harmonic connection between all living beings, everywhere, even the stars." He is drawn to Evan because he sees that Evan knows the music too. Wizard's music was there the night that Lyla and Louis met and his influence brings Evan ever closer to his parents, even if that is not his conscious intention.

Jamia Simone Nash is Hope, an absolutely adorable girl that not only steals every scene she is in, she leads Evan to Reverand James (Mykelti Williamson). Mykelti has been a personal favorite of mine since seeing him as "Bubba" in Forrest Gump, and he is lovely in his small part as someone who cares deeply about Evan and his gifts, ultimately helping him to get into Julliard.

If you are a fan of music, you will certainly enjoy this movie on that level alone. But if you open up to it and listen with your heart, you just might love it the way I do.

Freddie Highmore is remarkable as August Rush. Lost as an orphan, he is led into a gang of begging children run by their scary leader, Robin Williams. Unbeknownst to his mother (Keri Russell), she learns of his existence years after she believed he died at birth.  She is in search of her son, while Jonathan Rees-Meyers tries to find his lost love, Keri Russell.  The tangled searches involve the mash music of Keri Russell's cello solos, Jonathan Rees-Meyers haunting ballads, and Freddie Highmore's music genius riffs. It's one of those movies that will find you cheering for the characters in their search.

August Rush is a little cheesy, but such fun to watch.  Freddy Highmore is perfect in his role as a orphan (with a gift for hearing music in the world around him) on the loose in NYC searching for his parents. Robin Williams is oh-so believable as the less-than-honorable street musician who tries to exploit August's talent.  The story is a contrived and unbelievable - but if you view it as a fairy tale it's an highly entertaining film for adults as well as kids and may open up lots of interesting conversations.

The only thing that I didn't like was that the whole thing is based on (small spoiler alert) the result of a hook up between two people which happens at the very beginning of the movie. I mean, seriously, if you met the man/woman of your dreams with whom you had so much in common on an emotional level, wouldn't you spend the night getting to know one another by talking rather than having unprotected sex on a roof? Call me conservative, and I know that the whole story line would be different, but I work with high schoolers and didn't like the wreck less message that this part of the story conveyed.

TERRIFIC MOVIE - GIVING THIS AS A GIFT.  I ALREADY BOUGHT THIS FOR MYSELF BUT AM GIVING TO MY BOTHER ON HIS BIRTHDAY.

When you mix a nice story line, good characters, awesome music and unbelievable settings; you come up with something like August Rush.  It is not a complicated movie; but a good one, none the less.  I think it is great for the family, and I purchased a copy, specifically so that it can be shared with visitors, and watched over and over.  It has become one of my favorite films.

I just cannot believe I'd never heard of this gem of a movie! This is a movie for everyone-for family, for self, for anyone who loves music, who loves life, who has given up and needs a pick me up. From the very beginning I was uplifted by the music, and by the end I was crying by the music. One reviewer said this is a fairy tale, and it is-a modern day fairy tale--with everything a fairy tale needs! (Robin Williams playing a half-bad monster?) The young man who starred is just amazing. Kudos to everyone who had anything to do with 'August Rush'!

My mom wanted to purchase this movie after seeing the movie on TV. She said it was one of the best movies she had seen in years and wanted to purchase a few of them as gifts for people at church. Amazon would only allow 2 to be purchased at one time so we ordered the rest from Walmart.com for the same price but with free shipping to the store. Thanks Amazon for reminding us the we have other options from a site that does not put restrictions on the order limits.

Loved this story and the characters.  Robin Williams always delivers and the music is really interesting.  The little boy will steal your heart with his unfailing hope of finding his parents.  I really liked the sentiment behind the story.

I didn't think I would like this but once I got in to it, it was really good.  Robin Williams has played several less than savory characters in the past and his part in August Rush was borderline.  Overall, the movie was very enjoyable.

Such a moving, powerful story about love in many forms (parent to child, man to woman, social worker to child, brother to brother, and friend to friend). Also great music. Undeniably beautiful and one of my very favorites, with Robin Williams and some other fantastic performers!
i love this show. my last dvd was played too many times, so i had to get another one to replace it.

This is a really great movie, am so glad I have it. It's the kind of
movie you could watch over and over again. It's very moving.

This is one of the greatest stories of it's time. The determination on a young boy that enabled him to remain steadfast, even though many people tried to steal his dream. When I have a day that tries to snatch my dreams and vision for the future, I pull out this movie and watch it. It's one you'll keep in your library. One watching is absolutely not enough.
great movie awesome story line would deff recommend this to anyone family oriented just a smash hit my wife introduced it to me and I loved it

What a movie! This movie has become one of my favorites. I can't tell you with words how good it is. The story line is wonderful. Sometimes I think I'm watching Oliver Twist with a twist. I would love to see a sequel, although I'm sure that by now the characters have aged. I highly recommend August Rush--an uplifting movie.

Fantasy or not August Rush is a special movie made for those who like classical, rock and pop music. I thought for a long time on if something like this could ever happen. I think it could happen, but that is my humble opinion. Which is better, the music or the  movie? They are both equal and if you saw the theatrical version it is even better. It seems to me in this version something was cut out, but my memory could be slipping. Regardless it is a movie you should not miss.

Part Candide, part Oliver Twist... A inventive parable about listening to believing in and relying on your own voice to guide you to what is true... No matter how impossible this pursuit may be or the obstacles placed in your path.
The acting, particularly by the kids, is absolutely wonderful. I like how  the diversity of the casting and music styles is a unifying force in this film.
 favorite scenes:
1-Father and Son riffing on guitars in Washington Square Park( love the homage to Stanley Jordan playing style)
2- August playing Pipe Organ
This was an excellent movie of love and perseverance I loved the story and the acting was great. I would rent it again.
Augustus rush is one of those movies that just makes you believe and hope again and to never give up on your dream.  If you have a dream, protect it and don't let anybody steal it!
This is a have to watch movie you will have tears of Joy So order the movie and get your klenexx enjoy
I watched this at a friend's house and liked it so much I bought it.  Everything about it was wonderful!
I love this movie!  It is definitely one of my favorites!  It's one of those you can watch over, and over - buy it!
I love the music in this movie - the plot is a bit ridiculous, but it's entertaining.  I'm going to buy the soundtrack, though.

This is one of the finest, moving movies that I have seen. How we all would like to be able to hear music in everything around us. Great begining  and story line. Ending was beautiful and worthy of of fine movie
The best viewing was the first time when everything about the outcome was a surprise. This was the third time to see this movie and I thoroughly enjoyed it!
Unusual plot theme very well done.  Robin Williams was excellent in a quirky role. It's a movie you can watch several times and discover note of the movie each time
Good movie, especially if you are a music lover and especially if you like Guitar. Good story,  but kind of predictable.
A feel good movie for all ages! Missed it in the theatre now I get to watch it whenever I need a good movie day :)

Best movie ever made? No, but it is a very tender, emotional story. Keri Russell and Jonathan Rhys Meyers are totally believable as two young people who fall in love in the course of just one night, and Freddie Highmore pulls you in immediately. A sweet story.
The storyline coupled with outstanding talents in music is deep and very uplifting.  When we can afford it we'll get the CD soundtrack as the music is very powerful and touches your soul.
It is like a spin-off of Oliver Twist, but better.  I was totally enthralled. I loved it.  The boy never gave up.
This is a very nice movie. Glad I bought it. Haven't seen it?  You should you really won't be disappointed!
Such an inspiring movie. It works for all ages, we even bought a copy for our grandaughters! It's a movie you never get tired of watching.
We saw this movie in a theatre when it came out.  It's kind of long, but a great story! Good family movie.
I loved it so much!!!!! I'm in awe of Jonathan Rys Meyers he a great actor(: very emotional movie but you'll love it!!
I had seen this movie before, but had to rent through Amazon because I love it!  The music is great and I like the plot.  Good show!
Inspirational.
I really love this story. Sweet, hopeful and just slightly sad. It was interesting that Robin Williams played kinda the villian in the movie. Would recommend.
A  nice family movie with a really good musical score; though the movie does have that Hollywood ending  : )

For my class

Yes, I would recommend this movie to others because it is a wonderful and emotional movie to watch with a very happy ending. I loved the movie, and it captured my attention and kept me in suspense throughout the movie.

One of the most beautiful DVDs I've had the privilege of watching.  Realistic?  Not really.  Plausible?  Probably not.  A great, uplifting story which hearkens back to better times?  Absolutely.  I never considered that Snow White reflected  reality but that didn't lessen my enjoyment.  If you want cold reality, your local newspaper is a better source!  And besides - the music is great.
If you sing, compose, or just hear music in life you will love this movie. Rent it you will not be disapointed
This movie is such a "feel good" movie and all the actors did a great job. Loved to hear Jonathan Rhys Meyers singing.

My grandson is  living this movie. He is studying music at CalArts. He plays most of the woodwinds and is sell taught an several of them. I thought that the movie would be of interest to him as well as enjoyable to me. I was right.
Wonderful and moving story with stellar performances.  This film was thought-provoking, while entertaining.  The images used were appropriate and the score was superb.

This movie gives me goose bumps every time I watch it.  The music is very good.  The story line is wonderful. The boy named "August Rush" does a phenomenal acting job for his age.  The ending is warm, happy, exhilarating and extremely emotional.
What a wonderful feel good movie!  And the music was incredible! A really good family movie and Jonathan Rhys Meyers isn't hard on the eyes, either.

Music is my first love. It follows me everywhere I go, and I willingly let it. But most of the time, I am the one doing the following.

There is something about August Rush that I completely connected with. There is so much heart and soul in this film, that I become an emotional wreck ever time I watch it.

Freddie Highmore is so great! I have watched just about everything he has played in, and he continues to get better. I originally watched this movie because of Johnathan Rhys Meyers, because..well, do I really need an explanation. His voice is so, so incredibly sexy. And Robin Williams is beyond creepy in this part.

Anyways, the thought that music binds this entire family is beautiful. The way it all comes together in the end is spectacular. Again, I am an emotional wreck by the ending credits.

If you haven't seen August Rush yet, do it.

Great power movie that touches deep within that we are all connected and if we concentrate our power and energy in connecting and manifesting a connection and reconnection we can achieve it. Believe in yourself and a higher power and life will shine for you no matter how hard it gets or is. Life will get better and dreams do come true.
This is one of my family's all time favorite movies.  It was very cool that amazon sent me a suggestion for purchasing the soundtrack...I never knew there was one!!  So Thank YOU!!

Having raised a couple of very talented musicians I have a real connection with the energetic power of what music is at its core. This movie engulfed me it the magic of that power like no other movie I have seen. This movie has value for all ages and walks of life.
Great movie. This started my love for Jonathan Rhys Meyers. He is fantastic and So is this movie. Good times!
I bought this movie to replace the one I had lost.  Jonathan Rhys Meyers is at his best in this movie.  Love his music, if he had a band, I would buy his CD.
I have watched this movie over the years so many times, a lot of it is because of the music and how it is the thread that keeps everything together.
This movie is one of my all time favorites.  It is good for the entire family.  I loved it...Thanks for shipping so quickly

If you are looking for a movie for the entire family that will touch your heart, satisfy your soul, and leave feeling like anything is possible, then this is your movie. The music is superb, and the story is inspirational. You won't regret watching this wonderful movie!

The blood sugar spike you feel while you watch? Normal. It's there to dampen brain cells so you'll believe it's a good movie. Spandex doesn't stretch quite this far, but it's comfortable to believe the world operates this way, with everything working out in the end, and all the ugly fat of reality safely tucked away. Like most religions. Don't question, just enjoy the fantasy. :)
i always enjoyed the approach of a youth to music.  his journey gave hope. good musical development led me along
A great feel good movie. Perfect for the whole family! I highly recommend this movie for music lovers! Great movie!

If you love music or not, this one's not to be missed!
Definitely for people who can hear with their heart.
This is such an awesome movie. Really never heard much about it when it came out, but it pulls at your heart strings.

Didn't realize what an awesome singer Jonathon Rhys Meyers was. I've done some reading up on him and he is a very talented musician from County Cork, Ireland.  His family is also very musical. Big fan of his, he plays an awesome "Valentine" in "City of Bones".  The little boy, Freddie Highmore, Evan Taylor/August Rush does an excellent job acting in this film, as well as Keri Russell.  It is so happy when he is conducting his Rhapsody and at the end he knows he has played the music that brought his parents together and to him.  Robin Williams plays the Dark "Olympic" very well-I don't like it when he plays the bad guy.  Overall, I loved the movie, just had a hard time waiting for them to get back together.
I can watch this over and over. Great characters, great acting, but most of all I love the story. Gripping.

I enjoy this movie so much that I wanted my own to watch whenever I want. Love everyone in the movie and still makes me cry at the end no matter how many times I watch. And John Rhys-Myers is serious eye candy.

I really like this movie.  I tend to like  movies about someone or something.  It is an interesting story and a movie I can go back and watch over again.  Would recommend this movie if you like a good story and an interesting movie.
This is a heart-lifting story of a boy who never gives up. A young boy living in an orphanage believes the music he hears all around him will bring him to his true family. A beautiful tale.

The music choreography was excellent and captivating from the moment the movie began. The story line of the boy in search for his parents, being exploited, and then saved in more ways than one.  The actors in this movie did a wonderful job of bringing the strength of each character to the screen and the editors made it flow. Good job to the director and everyone who helped in the making this movie. It is worth every minute of ones time to watch.

Beautiful story. Our world needs more positive messages. There is way too much violence out there.
I will tell other to watch this movie.

Very few movies move me like this one to the point that I desire to watch it at least once a year and encourage all to watch.  Get different things out of it each time.
Awesome movie.
At this past New Years Eve dress up party, thought of this movie in futuristic light and painted my face blue with white notes on it....Hair the same.  Great fun!

This is a movie we enjoy watching over and over.
It is a great romantic movie. Wonderful gift item as well.
We've watched this movie many times over the years since purchasing it. The story is very interesting and emotional. It's a good, clean family movie.

Jan. 1st, 2014 5:28am  I was able to finally purchase the DVD, as well as the CD of This Movie!!!! THE MUSIC IS SO OUTSTANDING!!!!!  I Love how they incorporated the sounds of nature and noise of the city for August to be able to put it into music!!!!  I love this movie mostly because of the music and how they show how this lonely young boy used these sounds to create such magnificent music!!!!! It was his peace, enjoyment, and the driving forces that he felt would lead him to his parents!!!!
 So Beautiful, Heartwarming, movie!!!!! The only thing I did not like is when the leader [for the homeless children ] swore!  I felt the producers did not have to add that language into this movie!  But it does show the reality of what runaways may have to endure if they make that choice to runaway, and hopefully this movie can not only uplift such Beautiful Music, but show young people, that running away is not the right choice, because even though in this movie it had a excellent ending, but in reality it does not work out in such good endings!!!!  I was very glad that that through the sounds he heard, he translated it to the most beautiful  music!!!! And I Loved how they used the music he created to find his parents who both  themselves loved music even it was different kind of music for the father!!!  This Is A Must own DVD or CD!!!!! I have not heard the CD yet, it is on it's way to my home as well as the DVD, and I FEEL THE DVD IS A EXCELLENT MOVIE [EXCEPT for the  1 or 2 swear words[s] I can not remember] it shows the reality of can happen to young people who run away! And it also shows a good ending for a very talented boy looking for his parents, and his parents looking for him!!!!  But If Nothing else would touch your heart for this movie,... the music will , and you would want to hear it over and over again!!!1  Thank You for letting me speak on this movie!!!

Suspend your disbelief on some of the plot points and you'll enjoy it more ~ yes, this is the same Freddie that is now Norman Bates in BATES MOTEL on TV - if you're a musician as I am, you will REALLY appreciate the music and Robin Williams is amazing in his dark role. Jonathan and Keri have gone on to THE TUDORS and THE AMERICANS but are wonderful as cellist and singer.
The great thing about the DVD is how you can replay over and over your favorite parts ~ incredible low price for this classic movie.
This movie is a great movie. Its very moving and the ending is very specialMake sure your lady has tissue paper! I personally have watched it 4 or 5 times and still get emotional at the ending.
I loved this movie and the soundtrack for it!! The DVD showed up when I expected, in perfect condition and was a great purchase.
Very moving story with an predictable outcome,yet it draws you in anticipating the finale,super actors and music must see !
Great movie.. kind of cheesy. . But a feel good that hits all the right notes. Good story, solid acting, and a fantasy we all want to believe in.  What more could you want

First of all the actors are just right for the story. Freddie Highmore is outstanding as August Rush. Keri Russell and Jonathan Meyers as parents are perfect and Robin Williams, as always one of a kind. It is a good for the soul film.
What a lovely movie!  An engrossing story, even if it is an improbable scenario.  Loved it!  A story we want to believe of the power of love and music.

I'm an aspiring musician so I really enjoyed, August Rush. How music reunites a family.  Myself, & most of the general public agree, that it's just a nice feel good movie. Some critics miss the point, entirely. Actually, it may be more reality, than fantasy. Sometimes, people do reunite in what seem like a miracle situation. You have to open your mind. I just loved everything about the movie. The acting was good, but not overdone.  People just want to see a nice movie with people who persevere, even though as Freddie says " They try & take away, the music", & the desire to find, his parents. From the beginning you can tell all 3, of them know there is something missing, & strive to find, the answer. It seems most movies these days , have no ending, or you're disappointed,in the ending. August Rush had a perfect ending.

One of the most artistic pieces out of Hollywood in the past decade. Robin Williams in a villainous role, something you don't usually see which he does excellently, and who doesn't love Freddie Highmore. Excellent story and an even better sound track! Don't miss this one!

NEVER, EVER let anyone steal your dream; what you know to be true in your heart. This movie has so many redeeming qualities, but the portrayal of the deep, abiding love the 3 main characters have for each other is dominant.  Watch it with an open heart/mind and it will change your life.
This movie is timeless!

This movie is amazing.

Jonathan Rhys Meyers was fantastic, as always! And Freddie Highmore gave an outstanding performance!

This is a must see.
One of the best movies I've ever seen in my life. Music is outstanding. I own the mucus sountract also.

I had originally watched this movie when it came out on DVD and was amazed I had never heard of it.
The cast was fantastic. Robin Williams played his character perfectly.
This is a movie the entire family can watch. No nudity or bad language. I might of heard the word Damn once.
If you are a music lover, this movie will touch your soul. The young boy is a musical prodegey.
I have shared this movie with the very young and the very old and they all had the same reaction I did. LOVE LOVE LOVE it!!!! It is my new favorite movie of all time.
It is a must see.
great music - for anybody that loves love story's -- love's family story's --every song written for the movie was done so will for each setting
Watched it many times.  good for the kids too.  Some might say it is a bit over-done but my family really enjoyed it.
It was very touching and heartfelt....tear jerker for me. Reality comes to life in this movie. I would watch it again
I really enjoyed this movie. A friend had told me about it and suggested I purchase it. I'm glad I did. If you love music, you'll love this movie.

I love this movie because of the subject matter. This is one of those movies that fill you with joy and hope. You cheer for the young man and you are on edge, waiting with baited breath to see whether he will be successful. The music is truly heartwarming. This is a family movie!

I enjoyed the movie very much. A nice plot and good character development. Robin Williams takes on a new type of character, a little unlike him,  but he does it well. Freddie Highmore creates a wonderful character with a discovery of a hidden talent and love for music. The only thing I didn't like was his conducting style. He could have been coached much better to be more enthused and engaged in his method of utilizing the batton. Overall an enjoyable movie and one kids and adults alike would enjoy.
I wasn't able to load on my pc or tv.  Please credit my account for this amount $1.99. Could not watch the movie

This movie is a work of art.  Although somewhat of a fairy tale for a young man searching for his Mom thru his music, it is truly an amazing film.. And will be forever my best loved film of all time, for personal reasons..  Freddy Highmore is brilliant,
Magnificent music, great story line and superb casting.... this film is truly a masterpiece in reaching your heart and your spirit!
August Rush's continuous faith in the ability to find his parents against all odds is such a deep statement about knowing something deep inside even though you don't know the how of it.

My husband and I caught part of this movie while at a friends house and had to buy it to see the rest.  Love the music, characters and end.  Great family viewing and the ideas that it presents.  A must see if only for the pure enjoyment of music.

Because I love this movie very much and give it to my friends as a gift, so they can enjoy it too.
I personally love this movie and I'm so glad that I got it at such a low price and brand new! I would buy a movie from Freddie Highmore again!
Absolutely one of the best movies ever!!! Would definitely recommend this to anyone who has a heart .I loved it.
One of my favorite movies.  Excellent acting and story-telling.  Greatly enjoyed.  Child stayed true to himself despite others trying to get him to deny himself.
I am a fan of music and I love the story line of this movie. I do believe music does have a way of connecting people.

Moving story, great music, excellent characters. Recommended for any audience other than 5 and under.
warrants multiple viewings. Good stuff.
This is one of our favorite movies. We've watched it several times and always bring it out for a "feel good" movie. We love music and really enjoyed the message.
I wonderful schmaltzy film of discovery, triumph and love lost and found again. A joyful tear jerked! I will watch it again and again
this has to be one of the most amazing movies i have seen, it touch me so much!! specially the end OMG i cry like a baby!! it was an awesome movie, the little boy its a great actor.

Cool concept of the musical prodigy, some great concepts for the scenes with music, but poorly executed - in that it's VERY obvious the actors did not play the instruments. Storyline achingly predictable, characters very one sided, flashbacks confusing. A highly contrived story that's not very well told either.

GREAT music though!

Wonderful movie.  we have watched it 4 or 5 times and it is a keeper.  A real feel good movie without all the filthy language that most movies have today.  The little boy's acting is outstanding.  When we just want to see an entertaining movie we get this out and watch it again.  Have bought copies for other people as gifts.
This movie is a great movie for a family or just with some friends- it is uplifting with lots of music!
August Rush is a great inspirational and uplifting family movie with a novel story line and beautiful music.  A must see.
It was a very poignant story showing with a message to have faith and never give up . Very inspiring.
I LOVE THIS MOVIE! . It is the classic movie of child separated at birth from parents through no fault of their own and later reunited in a wonderful way. Good for the whole family to enjoy.
This is one of my family favorite DVD, It is so will played and it really touches your heart, Great price as well
It was a bit slow to start, but by the end it was very gripping and emotional - in a great way.

Wonderful Movie.
 LOVE, MUSIC, FAMILY, CREATIVE a Heartfelt story.
Reminds me of myself when I was homeless and discovered my music and parents in the park.
Perfect characters for this movie.  Loved the music and magic.  Will not tell you the story and spoil it for you.  A must see and keep.
What's not love about a story of a talented young boy who was empowered by a Mom who believed in him.  Rev. Dr. Jim Rush

I have always loved music but August Rush took me into  a most exhilarating dimension  of sound which turned the entire everyday world into a musical  instrument. I can never look at the guitar the same way as before, including the one leaning on the wall behind me. I am excited by the thought that I, too,, can make magic.

I have seen this movie several times online and liked it well enough to order my own copy.  Played it for several members of my family and they enjoyed it as well.  I tend to gravitate toward films in which a child carries the weight of the film and though everyone in the cast did a great job, it was Freddie Highmore's performance that captured my heart.

We loved this DVD.  We love guitar music and thought the story line was terrific.  The music was original and exciting.

There is nothing I do not love about this movie. It has been in my top five for several years. It is a beautiful unique love story with so much more.
this is my favorite movie of all time. music is my life and this movie portrays it and its power and affect perfectly.

This story is original in a way few movies are in today's world, mixing a kid's search for parents with listening/music.  After viewing it, I see and hear the world in a new way, more sensitive the the rhythms around me and the music inherent in life.
I loved this movie. Anyone who really enjoys music will love watching this young boy discover his talent and find his parents

We loved the story of music , sound and destiny !
The child in the story would not give up on his desire , he BELIEVED his parents would return for him
If he played his music.
Rented this movie, just cause, at Blockbuster - it is a WONDERFUL story!  Had to own a copy.  Happy with cost & delivery.  Thank you!
This is one of my favorite movies.  It has great music, great actors, and an amazing story.  I actually had this movie before, but lost it so I had to buy it again!
This movie has truly became one of my all time favorites.  Not only have I watched twice by myself, but when I have guest over, I suggest that we watch it.
From the first time I saw this movie, I knew it was destined to be on my all time favorite list!
This movie was recommended by a friend. I thought this movie was very enjoyable. I have suggested it to several other people.

Sweet/sad story of an innocent child; good people do exist and the movie ends on a happy note.
Little stary eyed, but relaxing on a rainy day.
Could watch it a thousand times.  The stars and music are wonderful.  Listen to the soundtrack while I take walks.
Sweet movie, sometimes a little slow but just the right thing for a quiet evening at home and the music is lovely.
I would recommend it to everyone, it tells us to listen to whats inside even if the rest of the world is telling you not to.
Finding yourself through sounds, then beats, then rythmns, then chords, then harmonies and finally through a melody that leads you home. Wonderful and engaging movie.

Great romantic film of a child's search for his parents and the star-crossed parents/lovers search for each other and their ultimately their child.  Hits all the right notes, with outstanding music throughout and especially at finale.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
One of the best movies ever made. So beautiful, touching, and inspirational! I could watch this movie over and over again

We have wanted to see this movie for years.  We are a musically talented family and appreciate many genres of music.  We were looking so forward to soaking the movie in through all things instrumental.  We were ready to be dazzled.  We were sorely and sadly disappointed.

Each of the main actors had about two facial expressions through the entire movie.  It felt like watching a sub-par high school play.  To add to the bad acting, Robin Williams was cast as the arch nemesis and played the same exact role he has played in a dozen other movies (Robin Williams as himself?).  Ugh.  I am annoyed when people talk during a movie, but you could not help it with this one...there were so many funny things to comment on...and it is not a comedy.

Everything about this movie seemed contrived, forced, unbelievable and downright silly.  There could be a web-site devoted to all the plot inconsistencies that ran throughout.

On the plus side, the soundtrack was great.

It's a beautiful story that our family truly enjoyed. I initially purchased it for my 9yr old son who is a guitar player. I wanted him to feel inspired by how well this young man plays. He was inspired. And he loved the story. Mission accomplished.
this is a great movie and I truly like the music and story line that made this a great story and something to enjoy
Freddie Highmore gave this role an innocence that was demanded of the character.  And he was the perfect "Oliver Twist" to Robin Williams' "Fagan".
Loved the movie.  Its one of my favorites!  will definately watch it again. I like older movies and I have my favorites and its one of them.

A great movie for both kids and adults. MY 10 yr old grand daughter and I watched the movie together. There were a couple things I had to explain a little deeper for her age group to understand but she watched the whole movie with me and says it is one of her very favorites... "except for the sad parts" she says!
This film provided an excellent plot for families, it hit home with fathers, mothers, and children all at the same time.

As a church organist I especially love the scene where August Rush discovered the pipe organ and explored the stops/pedal board and then the light came in through the stained glass windows -- this is exactly how I felt when I was young and discovering the instrument for myself.  As a member of a local orchestra I appreciate the classical aspects with the cellist/mother and as a woman who cannot do housecleaning with some rock n roll going in the background I like how the father/rocker finds a niche in everything around him.  Robin Williams acted his self-centered part well and it was fun to watch all the musical talent culminate.  If you listen there is music all around you -- that is no lie, and this film helps wake that feeling.  Yes, it is clichéd, but what can you do with 2 hours to weave a story?  This film does it about as best as it can be done.
One of my favorite movies. The music is inside you, follow your heart, and your dreams come true.  I hope you enjoy the movie.  I even have the music on my phone.
There truly is music everywhere. This movie is one that inspired me to take up piano lessons. Lost the first copy we had, this one is going into locked storage.

It was a very uplifting movie. I will never hear music in the same way again.
I open my eye (ears) as to what music can be.
The movie was a little slow at first but well worth the wait.

I have never seen a movie that touched me so deeply as this one did.  What a powerful story, great acting and good music.  It needs to have a sequel.  We need to see them all together, maybe like; August, where are you now or something.
One of my favorite movies of all times! Great for the whole family.  I recommend it to all of my friends.

i LIKE THIS.  WE ENJOY WATCHING THIS MOVIE.  UNFORTUNATELY WE HAVE MANY MOVIES AND NOT ENOUGH

I only wish the writers (or perhaps director?) had focused more efforts on the varying types of love capable within a family - you'll see what I mean - rather than introduce an outside business "family" structure as well.  But then again, maybe the contrast of the two adds to one's grasp of the familial love.  Either way, a true joy to watch as a family and as a couple.  Loved it.

August Rush should come with a warning: you may contract diabetes from watching this movie. What a load of romantic cliches and completely irrational crap! Movies like this perpetuate the myth that a one night stand whom you never see again is really your One True Love and if you find each other again, it will be happily ever after all the way. Yeah, right. I'd like to see this couple in five years when her habit of alphabetizing the canned goods is driving him nuts, and his leaving the toilet seat up is making her crazy.

Leave your common sense at the door if your going to watch this, because you'll be asked to believe that a healthy white male baby wouldn't immediately be fought over by multiple families who want to adopt him, but would instead be placed in some mythical home for orphan boys, which hasn't existed since Oliver Twist, that a hospital system would allow a child to be given up by the mother with just a signature, and not a lengthy conversation about why she doesn't want to keep her baby, and that a grown crazy man is housing multiple street urchins who stay with him voluntarily. You'll also be asked to believe (spoiler alert - as if anyone with more than two brain cells can't figure it out from the beginning) that two people who met once will find each other, and their long-lost son eleven years later in a city of millions of people without much trouble at all. The breathless dialog and faux angst between and among characters is nauseating. Avoid this movie like the plague or you may drop a few dozen IQ points in just over an hour.

I watched August Rush for the first time on a Sunday late-afternoon while flicking through TV channels. Of course, I didn't caught it from the beginning, and that happened every time since, whenever I found it on TV. I decided to purchase the DVD, not only because I wanted to watch it in its entirety for once and for all but also because it had always touched me from the middle onwards, which was always the part caught by me.

Evan's life-journey, with the music inside him leading the way, had kind of a sad and beautiful impact on me. Another thing that allowed watching the movie from the beginning is that I was finally able to understand all the musical connections between Lyla, Louis and August. You could say that not being able to caught a movie right from the start takes some of its magic away. But in this case it was the opposite, because every time I became aware of a harmonic blending between two different performances or theme that eventually becomes part of August's Rhapsody, I couldn't help but cheering those special moments.

August Rush is a great movie all by itself. But being a musician and music lover too I felt the experience to be much greater than watching any other movie that has a complete different topic. So I recommend this DVD to anybody who'd like to witness a fairy-tale story and be soared by touching melodies.

This is absolutely one of the worst, sappiest, melodramatic, illogical movies I've seen in a long time.  I mean, we're going along and its sappy and teary and all.  OK, fine.  But then we come to the part where the kid finds this old guitar in the attic or something and immediately starts playing like Kaki King.  That's where I lost it. There is just no way this is going to happen no matter how much innate talent the kid has.  Kaki King plays her unique style on a finely tuned, custom-made instrument.  Nobody is going to pick up an old guitar and immediately sound like this.  Anyone who could believe this knows absolutely nothing about music.  There is just no way.

If you want a sappy love story with no basis in the real world, then this might be the movie for you.

Loosely based on Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist, this family-friendly film tells the story of a young boy, Evan Taylor, who has grown up in an orphanage without knowing his parents. After running away from the orphanage, Evan, played by Freddie Highmore, changes his name to August Rush and begins a stint as a street musician working for a modern day Fagan named Wizard, played by Robin Williams. We are supposed to believe that Evan, now August, has an innate musical genius that allows him to hear music in the air and to pick up a guitar and immediately start playing it. He also teaches himself to read and compose musical scores in the space of an afternoon. On the basis of his musical genius, he is soon accepted into Juilliard as a twelve year old and  is asked to headline an outdoor orchestral concert in Central park. If you know the plot of Oliver twist, you can guess the outcome of this movie, as invisible forces move the characters toward its inevitable conclusion.
On the plus side, the movie is about the power of music, and features several heartfelt performances by Evan's father, played by Jonathan Rhys Meyers, and by his mother, played by the beautiful Keri Russell. Victorius's own Leon Thomas provides support in the role of Arthur, the August Rush equivalent of The Artful Dodger. Although hopelessly sentimental, August Rush is the most derivative, uninspired, unbelievable, predictable movie that will ever love.
It is a wonderful story of hope and faith.  Mostly I love the music.  I would recommend this to my friends and even my enemies.

Let me be up front right now.  This movie is more about faith and music connecting everybody than anything.  The story begins with Keri Russel and Jonathan Rhys Meyers playing Lyla and Louis, 2 individuals involved in music in different ways.  Lyla is with the philharmonic and Louis is in a band.  They meet one night, have a deep connection and then Lyla is forced away by her father.  Lyla becomes pregnant and ends up in an accident.  Her father tells her the baby died, but we then turn to the baby turned into an 11 year old at a boys home.  The story then becomes about Evan (August Rush) and his journey throughout New York in order to play his music to find his parents.  There are some really great moments in the movie, but you have to be able to put doubt about Lyla hearing Evan's symphony and knowing that is her son aside and just enjoy the movie.

This movie is full of heart and compassion, love and caring. It's a story of how music can affect us if we let it, how music can bring us together if we allow it to do so.  August's journey back to his parents is a lovely parable of the importance of passion in our lives, and the willingness to continue a journey even when things look their bleakest.  The acting is top-notch, the script works extremely well, and the characters are finely drawn and work all the way around.  A lovely experience.

We are also provided with an "escape from realism" that brings us down. It raises our spirits, giving us an emotional boost that most of us can benefit from.

Louis Connelly, an Irish musician burned out on music and Lyla Novacek, a professional cellist, share a chance magical evening. The result is a child who the father does not know exists and the mother believes died stillborn in a car accident. In reality, the child was put up for adoption by the mother's controlling father. Now, years later, the boy August Rush is searching for parents that do not even know he exists. August, a musical prodigy who can hear music in the random sounds of everyday life, is convinced he can use his remarkable musical talent to reunite himself with the parents he has never known. He has a chance encounter with his father (neither knows who the other is) and both play guitars in a scene reminiscent of "Dueling Banjos" in Deliverance. In the latter half of the movie, the mother finds out from her father that her baby did not die in the car accident and she goes looking for him. But how can mother and son be reunited when neither knows the others name or location? Love of music will draw the father, the mother and the lost son together in one magical moment in space and time.

Yes, the movie is unrealistic. Yes, it has fairy tale elements. Yes, it is a combination of Oliver Twist (young orphan travels to London and meets the Artful Dodger, leader of a gang of pickpockets) and Harry Potter (young wizard orphan in search of knowledge about his dead parents). But the movie works to pull you in. The musical scenes are magical. This is a feel good movie with a happy ending. If that is your kind of movie, you will love this film.

Though at first, it was rather difficult to get the image of King Henry out of my mind when Jonathan Rhys Meyers appeared. Very good story and one the whole family can watch.

What's most irritating about it is that it tries so hard to be inspirational but the story about a kid with such "talent" that he can just pick up the guitar for the first time and play it masterfully or compose a complicated symphony that gets a huge production in NYC focusses on the glory of natural (read "unnatural") talents. Give me a story about someone who struggles against all odds, practicing and studying and working hard to be the best they can be. That would be inspirational. August Rush was a movie about a bizarre kid, an unsettling story in which the adults around him treat him like the second coming. Yuck.

Now for starters, this film is very hyphy. When investors "Keak Tha Sneak" and "Kool Keith" decided to executive produce a film about music lovers, they had no idea what they were getting into. Apparently this was supposed to be a monumental film on the scale of "Citizen Cane" meets "Transformers the Movie" starring Kevin Spacey as a ten-year old orphan who discovers the magic power of death metal while being August Rushed in a cornfield. However, Spacey stepped out at the last moment to film "Pay It Forward 2: Electric Boogaloo." So instead we got this film about an actual orphan who directs wheat, to see how much it will yield. After meeting the pimp from "Hustle and Flow," the young prodigy leaves and wanders into the woods, where he mistakes a wolf for a cello. Upon reaching the big apple, he meets Garp, who teaches him how to play acoustic versions of Tool songs on a wolf. I can't really recommend higher than five stars, because they won't allow me, but the score by Cannibal Corpse (working with famed rapper First Degree The D.E.) really boosts this film into a level of transcendence rarely seen in this era of big-budget blockbusters with no soul. The film is also filled out by U2 singer "Bono" who plays the young man's father. Pay it forward indeed.
